title: Congruence generated by a set
text:
Let us consider \(p \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed. Given \(\tau \in \mathbb{N}^p \times \mathbb{N}^p\), the congruence generated by \(\tau\) is the smallest congruence on \(\mathbb{N}^p\) containing \(\tau\), and it is denoted by \(cong(\tau)\).
It can be proven that \(cong(\tau)\) is the intersection of all congruences containing it.

title: Congruence generated by a set
text:
Let us consider \(p \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed. Given \(\tau \in \mathbb{N}^p \times \mathbb{N}^p\), the congruence generated by \(\tau\) is the smallest congruence on \(\mathbb{N}^p\) containing \(\tau\), and it is denoted by \(cong(\tau)\).
It can be proven that \(cong(\tau)\) is the intersection of all congruences containing it.

title: Congruence generated by a set
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(\tau = \{(7, 14), (20, 22), (39, 7), (20, 13), (7, 7)\} \subseteq \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\). For \(\tau\) to be an equivalence relation, we define the sets \(A_1, A_2\) and \(A_3\) as
\[
A_1 = \{(7,7), (13, 13), (14,14), (20,20), (22,22), (39,39) \},
\]
\[
A_2 = \{(14, 7), (22,20), (7, 39), (13, 20)\},
\]
\[
A_3 = \{(39, 14), (14, 39), (22,13), (13,22)\}.
\]
It is easy to prove that \(\tau' = \tau \cup \left( \bigcup_{i = 1}^3 A_i \right)\) is an equivalence. Now, \(\tau'\) will be a congruence if for all pairs \((a,b) \in \tau_3\) and for all \(u \in \mathbb{N}\), it holds \((a + u, b + u) \in \tau'\), then we have to add the set
\[
B = \{(a + u, b + u) ~ | ~ (a, b) \in \tau', u \in \mathbb{N} \}.
\]
Finally, the congruence of \(\tau\) is \(cong(\tau) = \tau' \cup B\).

title: Standard representation in a free Numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. The definition of standard representation in a free numerical semigroup comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Proposition}\): Assume that \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\), and let \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\). There exist unique \(\lambda_0, \lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_h \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that the following holds.

\(\displaystyle x = \sum_{k = 0}^h \lambda_k r_k\).
For all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\), \(0 \le \lambda_k < e_k\).

It is defined the standard representation of an integer \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) an expression of \(x\) like in the previous proposition.

title: Standard representation in a free Numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. The definition of standard representation in a free numerical semigroup comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Proposition}\): Assume that \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\), and let \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\). There exist unique \(\lambda_0, \lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_h \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that the following holds.

\(\displaystyle x = \sum_{k = 0}^h \lambda_k r_k\).
For all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\), \(0 \le \lambda_k < e_k\).

It is defined the standard representation of an integer \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) an expression of \(x\) like in the previous proposition.

title: Standard representation in a free Numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Consider the free numerical semigroup \(S = \langle 4, 6, 9 \rangle\) and the integer \(x = 27\). The unique ways to generate \(x\) from the set \(B = \{4, 6, 7\}\) are with the coefficients \(a_1 = (3, 1, 1), a_2 = (0, 3, 1)\) and \(a_3 = (0, 0, 3)\). We have, \(d_1 = r_0 = 4\), \(d_2 = gcd(d_1, r_1) = gcd(4, 6) = 2\), \(d_3 = gcd(d_2, r_2) = gcd(2, 9) = 1\), \(e_1 = \frac{d_1}{d_2} = 2, e_2 = \frac{d_2}{d_3} = 2\). Checking the second condition on each \(a_i\) with \(i = 1,2,3\), it holds that the standard representation of \(x = 27\) with respect to \(S\) is \((3, 1, 1)\).

title: Stable ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with reduction number \(r(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is stable if \(r(E) = 1\), that is, \(2E = m(E) + E\).

title: Stable ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with reduction number \(r(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is stable if \(r(E) = 1\), that is, \(2E = m(E) + E\).

title: Stable ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\), \(I = \{2, 4\}\) and \(E = I + S = \{2, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \}\). Clearly, \(m(E) = 2\), then we are looking for the smaller \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) such that \((h+1)E = 2 + hE\). If we take \(h = 1\),
\[
2E = E + E = \{4, 6, \rightarrow\} \ne \{4, 6, 7, 9, \rightarrow \} = 2 + E.
\]
Therefore, \(E\) is not stable. It is easy to prove that \(r(E) = 2\).

title: Irreducible ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as finite intersection of proper ideals of \(S\) strictly containing it.
If \(D(X)\) denotes the set of divisors of x in \(S\), it can be proven that every irreducible ideal containing \(E\) is of the form \(S \setminus D(x)\), with \(x \in S \setminus E\) and the intersection of all this sets is equal to \(E\).

title: Irreducible ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as finite intersection of proper ideals of \(S\) strictly containing it.
If \(D(X)\) denotes the set of divisors of x in \(S\), it can be proven that every irreducible ideal containing \(E\) is of the form \(S \setminus D(x)\), with \(x \in S \setminus E\) and the intersection of all this sets is equal to \(E\).

title: Irreducible ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Any numerical semigroup \(S\) is irreducible as ideal of itself.
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle = \{0, 3, 5, \rightarrow \}\), \(I = \{3, 5\}\) and \(E = I + S\). First, we compute \(S \setminus E\),
\[
E = I + S = (3 + S) \cup (5 + S) = \{3, 6, 8, \rightarrow \} \cup \{5, 8, 10, \rightarrow \} = \{3, 5, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}.
\]
Therefore, \(S \setminus E = \{0, 7\}\) and \(E \subseteq (S \setminus D(0)) \cap (S \setminus D(7))\), but \(S \setminus D(0) = S^*\) and \(S \setminus D(7) = E\), then \(E\) is a irreducible ideal of \(S\).

title: Irreducible ideal
Irreducible ideal

title: Arf semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(S\) is Arf if every integrally closed proper ideal of \(S\) is stable. It can be proven that a numerical semigroup \(S\) is Arf if, and only if, for any \(s,t \in S\) with \(s \le t\), it holds \(2t - s \in S\).

title: Arf semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(S\) is Arf if every integrally closed proper ideal of \(S\) is stable. It can be proven that a numerical semigroup \(S\) is Arf if, and only if, for any \(s,t \in S\) with \(s \le t\), it holds \(2t - s \in S\).

title: Arf semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\), \(I = \{9, 10, 12, 14\}\) and \(E = I + S\). It is easy to prove that \(E = (9 + \mathbb{N}) \cap S = S(9)\), then \(E\) is integrally closed, but \(r(E) = 2\), since
\[
2E = E + E = \{18, \rightarrow \} \ne \{18, 19, 21, 23, \rightarrow \} = m(E) + E,
\] and
\[
3E = E + (E + E) = \{27, \rightarrow \} = m(E) + 2E.
\]
Therefore, \(E\) is integrally closed but not stable. Thus, \(S\) is not an Arf semigroup.
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle = \{0, 3, 5, \rightarrow \}\), let’s prove that for any \(s,t \in S\) with \(s \le t\), it holds \(2t - s \in S\). The conductor of \(S\) is \(C(S) = 5\), we divide into cases:

If \(t < C(S)\): if \(t < C(S) = 5\), it must be \(t = 0\) or \(t = 3\) and the property holds easily.
If \(t \ge C(S)\): let \(s \in S\) with \(s \le t\). Then, \(2t - s = t + (t-s) \ge t \ge C(S)\) and \(2t - s \in S\).

Therefore, \(S\) is an Arf semigroup. In fact, we have proven that \(S\) is Arf if, and only if, for any \(s \in S\), \(t \in N(S)\) with \(s \le t\), where \(N(S)\) denotes the set of left elements of \(S\), it holds \(2t - s \in S\).

title: Arf semigroup
Arf semigroup

title: Almost canonical ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with Frobenius number \(F(S)\) and genus \(g(S)\), and let \(E\) be a proper ideal with Frobenius number ideal \(F(E)\) and type ideal \(t(E)\). If \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\), it is said that \(E\) is an almost canonical ideal if \(g(\tilde{E}) + m(\tilde{E}) = F(S) - g(S) + t(E)\), where \(g(\tilde{E})\) and \(m(\tilde{E})\) refers to the genus of an ideal and the multiplicity of an ideal, respectively.

title: Almost canonical ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with Frobenius number \(F(S)\) and genus \(g(S)\), and let \(E\) be a proper ideal with Frobenius number ideal \(F(E)\) and type ideal \(t(E)\). If \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\), it is said that \(E\) is an almost canonical ideal if \(g(\tilde{E}) + m(\tilde{E}) = F(S) - g(S) + t(E)\), where \(g(\tilde{E})\) and \(m(\tilde{E})\) refers to the genus of an ideal and the multiplicity of an ideal, respectively.

title: Almost canonical ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(E = \{10, 12, 14\} + S\). With simple calculations it is obtained that \(E \subseteq S\) (is a proper ideal), \(F(S) = 13, g(S) = 8\), \(F(E) = 18\) and \(t(E) = 3\). On the other hand, \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E) = E - 5\), \(g(\tilde{E}) = 6\) and \(m(\tilde{E}) = 5\). Finally, \(F(S) - g(S) + t(E) = 13 - 8 + 3 = 8 \ne 11 = g(\tilde{E}) + m(\tilde{E})\). To sum up, \(E\) is not an almost canonical ideal.

title: Almost canonical ideal
Almost canonical ideal

title: Conductor ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the conductor ideal of \(S\) as the set \(S - \mathbb{N} = \{z \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ z + \mathbb{N} \subseteq S \}\). Equivalently, the conductor ideal of \(S\) is defined as the numerical semigroup \(S - \mathbb{N} = \{C(S), \rightarrow \}\), where \(C(S)\) denotes the conductor of \(S\).

title: Conductor ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the conductor ideal of \(S\) as the set \(S - \mathbb{N} = \{z \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ z + \mathbb{N} \subseteq S \}\). Equivalently, the conductor ideal of \(S\) is defined as the numerical semigroup \(S - \mathbb{N} = \{C(S), \rightarrow \}\), where \(C(S)\) denotes the conductor of \(S\).

title: Conductor ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 8, 11 \rangle\). Computing the first elements of \(S\), it is obtained that \(S = \{0, 5, 8, 10, 11, 13, 15, 16, 18, \rightarrow \}\), thus \(C(S) = 18\) and \(S - \mathbb{N} = \{18, \rightarrow \}\).

title: Conductor ideal

title: Blowup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with multiplicity ideal \(m(E)\) and reduction number \(r(E)\). It is defined the blowup of \(E\) as the proper ideal \(r(E)E - r(E)m(E)\). It is denoted by \(\mathcal{B}(E)\).
It can be proven that \(r(E)E - r(E)m(E) = r(E)E - r(E)E\).

title: Blowup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with multiplicity ideal \(m(E)\) and reduction number \(r(E)\). It is defined the blowup of \(E\) as the proper ideal \(r(E)E - r(E)m(E)\). It is denoted by \(\mathcal{B}(E)\).
It can be proven that \(r(E)E - r(E)m(E) = r(E)E - r(E)E\).

title: Blowup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\), \(I = \{2, 4\}\) and \(E = I + S = \{2, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \}\). Clearly, \(m(E) = 2\), then we are looking for the smaller \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) such that \((h+1)E = 2 + hE\). If we take \(h = 1\),
\[
2E = E + E = \{4, 6, \rightarrow\} \ne \{4, 6, 7, 9, \rightarrow \} = 2 + E.
\]
For \(h = 2\),
\[
3E = (E + E) + E = \{6, 8, \rightarrow\} = 2 + 2E
\]
To sum up, \(r(E) = 2\) and the blowup of \(E\) is \(2E - 2E = \{0, 2, \rightarrow \}\).

title: Blowup
Blowup

title: Type of an ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the type of \(E\) as \(t(E) = |(E - M) \setminus E|\), where \(M = S^*\) is the maximal ideal of \(S\).

title: Type of an ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the type of \(E\) as \(t(E) = |(E - M) \setminus E|\), where \(M = S^*\) is the maximal ideal of \(S\).

title: Type of an ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) The definition of type of a relative ideal is a generalization of the type of a numerical semigroup. Indeed, let \(S\) a numerical semigroup with type \(t\), in particular, is a relative ideal of itself, then \(t(S) = |(S - S^*) \setminus S|\). By definition,
\[
S - S^* = \{z \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ z + S^* \subseteq S\},
\]
then, the set \((S - S^*) \setminus S\) is the set of pseudo-Frobenius number of \(S\), in conclusion, \(t(S) = t\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 11 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 10, 11, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(E = \{-4\} + S = \{-4, 1, 3, 6, 7, 8, 10, \rightarrow\}\). We have,
\[
E - S^* = \{z \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ z + S^* \subseteq E\}
\]
The candidates are in the set \(\{-9, -8, \ldots, 9\} \setminus E\), and checking for every element, we get \(E - S^* = \{5, 9\}\) and \(t(E) = 2\).

title: Type of an ideal
Type of an ideal
text: References

title: Genus of an ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the genus of \(E\) as \(g(E) = |(m(E) + \mathbb{N}) \setminus E|\), where \(m(E)\) denotes the multiplicity of \(E\).

title: Genus of an ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the genus of \(E\) as \(g(E) = |(m(E) + \mathbb{N}) \setminus E|\), where \(m(E)\) denotes the multiplicity of \(E\).

title: Genus of an ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(E = \{-14\} + S = \{-14, -9, -7, -5, -4, -2, 0, \rightarrow\}\). Clearly, \(m(E) = -14\), so \(g(E) = |(-14 + \mathbb{N}) \setminus E| = |\{-13, -12, -11, -10, -8, -6, -3, -1\}| = 8\).
\(\circ\) The definition of genus of a relative ideal is a generalization of the genus of a numerical semigroup. Indeed, let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with genus \(g\), in particular, is a relative ideal of itself, then \(g(S) = |(m(S) + \mathbb{N}) \setminus S|\). The multiplicity of \(S\) is \(m(S) = 0\), therefore \(g(S) = |\mathbb{N} \setminus S| = g\).

title: Genus of an ideal
text:
Examples with GAP

title: Set closed under divisors
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(\le_S\) the relation order of \(S\) and \(X\) a subset of \(\mathbb{N}\). It is said that \(X\) is closed under divisors if for all \(x \in X\) and \(y \in S\), if \(y \le_S x\), then \(y \in X\).

title: Set closed under divisors
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(\le_S\) the relation order of \(S\) and \(X\) a subset of \(\mathbb{N}\). It is said that \(X\) is closed under divisors if for all \(x \in X\) and \(y \in S\), if \(y \le_S x\), then \(y \in X\).

title: Set closed under divisors
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let’s prove that if \(E\) is a proper ideal of \(S\), then its complement \(X = S \setminus E\) is closed under divisors. Let \(x \in X\) and \(y \in S\) such that \(y \le_S x\), therefore exists \(s \in S\) so that \(x = y + s\). If we suppose \(y \not \in X\), then \(y \in E\) and \(x = s + y \in S + E \subseteq E\), a contradiction. In conclusion, \(y \in X\) and \(X\) is closed under divisors.

title: Set closed under divisors
Set closed under divisors

title: Integrally closed ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is integrally closed if it is of the form \(S(s) = (s + \mathbb{N}) \cap S\) for some \(s \in S\).
It can be proven that \(E\) is integrally closed if, and only if, \(E = S(m(E))\), where \(m(E)\) denotes the multiplicity ideal of \(E\).

title: Integrally closed ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is integrally closed if it is of the form \(S(s) = (s + \mathbb{N}) \cap S\) for some \(s \in S\).
It can be proven that \(E\) is integrally closed if, and only if, \(E = S(m(E))\), where \(m(E)\) denotes the multiplicity ideal of \(E\).

title: Integrally closed ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup, then the maximal ideal \(M = S^*\) is integrally closed, since \(S^* = (m(S) + \mathbb{N}) \cap S\), where \(m(S)\) denotes the multiplicity of \(S\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\), \(I = \{9, 10, 12, 14\}\) and \(E = I + S\), lets prove the equality \(E = (9 + \mathbb{N}) \cap S\). First, \((9 + \mathbb{N}) \cap S = \{9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow\}\), then we have to prove that \(E = \{9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow\}\).

Let \(e \in E\), then exist \(i \in I\) and \(s \in S\) such that \(e = i + s\). If \(s = 0\), \(e \in I \subseteq \{9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow\}\), otherwise, \(e = i + s \ge i + 5 \ge 14\) and \(e \in \{9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow\}\).
It is easy to check that \(\{14, 15, 16, 17, 18\} \subseteq E\), then for all \(n \ge 14\) it holds \(n \in E\) and \(\{9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow\} \subseteq E\).

title: Integrally closed ideal
Integrally closed ideal

title: Maximum sparse ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with genus \(g(S)\) and Frobenius number \(F(S)\), and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with Frobenius number ideal \(F(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is a maximum sparse ideal if satisfies the equality \(F(E) = 2g(S) - 1 + |S \setminus E|\).
If the multiplicity of a relative ideal is denoted by \(m(E)\) and the genus of a relative ideal by \(g(E)\), it can be proven that the equality is equivalent to \(F(S) + 1 - g(S) = g(\tilde{E}) + m(\tilde{E})\), where \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\).

title: Maximum sparse ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with genus \(g(S)\) and Frobenius number \(F(S)\), and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with Frobenius number ideal \(F(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is a maximum sparse ideal if satisfies the equality \(F(E) = 2g(S) - 1 + |S \setminus E|\).
If the multiplicity of a relative ideal is denoted by \(m(E)\) and the genus of a relative ideal by \(g(E)\), it can be proven that the equality is equivalent to \(F(S) + 1 - g(S) = g(\tilde{E}) + m(\tilde{E})\), where \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\).

title: Maximum sparse ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9 \rangle\) and the proper ideal \(E = \{F(S) + 1, \rightarrow \}\) (in fact, is the conductor ideal of \(S\)). In this case, \(E = \tilde{E}\), and is easy to check that \(F(S) = F(E) = 11, g(S) = 6, g(E) = 0\) and \(m(E) = F(S) + 1\), then \(F(S) + 1 - g(S) = 6 < 12 = m(E)\), thus \(E\) is not a maximum sparse ideal.
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup and \(K(S)\) the standard canonical ideal of \(S\). The integer \(g(K) + m(K)\) is the number of elements in \(\mathbb{N} \setminus K\) since \(m(K)\) is a non-negative integer. Furthermore, \(F(S) + 1 - g(S)\) is the number of elements \(s \in S\) such that \(s \le F(S) + 1\). By the bijection \(\{0, 1, \ldots, F(S) + 1\} \cap S \to \mathbb{N} \setminus K\) defined by \(s \to F(S) - s\), we have the equality \(F(S) + 1 - g(S) = m(K) + g(K)\). To sum up, \(K(S)\) is always a maximum sparse ideal of \(S\).

title: Maximum sparse ideal
text:
Examples with GAP
Nowadays, there are no functions in package NumericalSgps related to maximum sparse ideal.

title: Maximum sparse ideal

title: Numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(e(S)\) the embedding dimension and \(m(S)\) the multiplicity of \(S\). Then, it is said that \(S\) is a numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension if \(e(S) = m(S)\).
It is well known that for every numerical semigroup, it holds the inequality \(e(S) \le m(S)\).

title: Numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(e(S)\) the embedding dimension and \(m(S)\) the multiplicity of \(S\). Then, it is said that \(S\) is a numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension if \(e(S) = m(S)\).
It is well known that for every numerical semigroup, it holds the inequality \(e(S) \le m(S)\).

title: Numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 8 \rangle\). Clearly, \(m(S) = 3\) and \(e(S) = 2\), thus \(S\) does not have maximal embedding dimension.
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(a,b \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(gcd(a,b) = 1\) and \(S = \langle a, a+1, a+2, \ldots, a+b \rangle\). By construction of \(S\), \(m(S) = a\). To compute \(e(S)\), we divide into cases:

If \(a = b\), then \(B = {a, a+1, \ldots, 2a - 1}\) is the minimal set of generators of \(S\) and \(e(S) = a\), therefore \(S\) has maximal embedding dimension.
If \(a \ne b\), then \(B = \{a, a+1, \ldots, a+b\}\) is the minimal set of generators of \(S\), \(e(S) = b\) and \(S\) does not have maximal embedding dimension.

title: Numerical semigroup with maximal embedding dimension

title: Almost symmetric numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number, \(g(S)\) the genus and \(t(S)\) the type of \(S\). It is said that \(S\) is an almost symmetric numerical semigroup if it satisfies the equality \(2g(S) = F(S) + t(S)\).

title: Almost symmetric numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number, \(g(S)\) the genus and \(t(S)\) the type of \(S\). It is said that \(S\) is an almost symmetric numerical semigroup if it satisfies the equality \(2g(S) = F(S) + t(S)\).

title: Almost symmetric numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14\}\). It is easy to see that the set of gaps is \(G(S) = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 11, 13\}\), the Frobenius number is \(F(S) = 13\) and the set of pseudo-Frobenius numbers is \(PF(S) = \{11, 13\}\). Therefore, \(g(S) = |G(S)| = 8, t(S) = |PF(S)| = 2\) and \(2g(S) = 16 \ne 15 = 13 + 2 = F(S) + t(S)\), to sum up, \(S\) is not an almost symmetric numerical semigroup.
\(\circ\) Let \(a,b \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(gcd(a,b) = 1\) and \(S = \langle a, b \rangle\). It is well known that for numerical semigroups of embedding dimension two, \(t(S) = 1\) and \(2g(S) = F(S) + 1 = F(S) + t(S)\), therefore, every numerical semigroup with embedding dimension two is almost symmetric.

title: Symmetric numerical semigroup
text: A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be symmetric if it is irreducible and its Frobenius number is odd.

title: Symmetric numerical semigroup
text: A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be symmetric if it is irreducible and its Frobenius number is odd.

title: Symmetric numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 10, 17 \rangle\). This numerical semigroup is irreducible and if we compute the first elements of \(S\), we obtain that \(S = \{0, 4, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 22, 24, \rightarrow \}\), so \(F(S) = 23\) and \(S\) is a symmetric numerical semigroup.

title: Weierstrass semigroup
text: Let \(C\) be a smooth algebraic curve over the complex numbers of genus \(g\). Weierstrass Lückensatz states that for every \(P \in C\), there are exactly \(g\) integers \(\alpha_1(P), \alpha_2(P), \ldots, \alpha_g(P)\) with \(1 = \alpha_1(P) < \cdots < \alpha_g(P) = 2g - 1\), such that for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, g\}\) there is no meromorphic function on \(X\) with a pole at \(P\) of multiplicity \(\alpha_i(P)\) as its only singularity. The set \(S = \mathbb{N} \setminus \{\alpha_1(P), \alpha_2(P), \ldots, \alpha_g(P)\}\) is a numerical semigroup, known as the Weierstrass semigroup at \(P\).

title: Tschirnhausen transform
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Let us consider \(d\) a divisor of \(n\) and let \(G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be a monic polynomial of degree \(\frac{n}{d}\) in \(y\). Then, the G-adic expansion of \(f\) has the form
\[
f = G^d + \alpha_1 G^{d-1} + \cdots + \alpha_d,
\]
with \(\alpha_i \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) and \(deg_y \alpha(x,y) < \frac{n}{d}\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, d\}\). It is defined the Tschirnhausen transform of \(G\) as \(T(G) = G + \frac{\alpha_1}{d}\).

title: Tschirnhausen transform
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Let us consider \(d\) a divisor of \(n\) and let \(G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be a monic polynomial of degree \(\frac{n}{d}\) in \(y\). Then, the G-adic expansion of \(f\) has the form
\[
f = G^d + \alpha_1 G^{d-1} + \cdots + \alpha_d,
\]
with \(\alpha_i \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) and \(deg_y \alpha(x,y) < \frac{n}{d}\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, d\}\). It is defined the Tschirnhausen transform of \(G\) as \(T(G) = G + \frac{\alpha_1}{d}\).

title: Tschirnhausen transform
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(f = y^6 + (12x^2 + 3)y^5 + (36x^4 + 18x^2 + 2)y^4 + 13xy^3 + (78x^3 + 2x^2 + 20x)y^2 + 42x^2\) and \(g = y^3 + (6x^2 + 1)y^2 + 7x\). We have \(n = 6\) and \(d = 2\). Dividing,
\[
f = (y^3 + (6x^2 + 2)y^2 + 6x)G + 2x^2y^2 = QG + R,
\]
and \(deg_y Q = 3 = deg_y G\). Dividing \(Q\) by \(G\),
\[
Q = G + y^2 - x = Q^1G + R^1.
\]
Then, the \(G-\)adic expansion of \(f\) is
\[
f = QG + R = (Q^1G + R^1)G + R = G^2 + (y^2 - x)G + 2x^2y^2,
\]
with \(\alpha_1(x,y) = y^2 - x\). Finally, the Tschirnhausen transform of \(G\) is
\[
T(G) = G + \frac{\alpha_1(x,y)}{d} = y^3 + (6x^2 + 1)y^2 + 7x + \frac{y^2-x}{2}.
\]

title: Numerical semigroup associated to a curve
text:
The definition of numerical semigroup associated to a curve needs the following preposition.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(F = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x)\) be a nonzero polynomial of \(\mathbb{K}[x][y]\) and assume, possibly after a change of variables, that \(deg_x a_i < i\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\) such that \(a_i(x) \ne 0\). Let \(F_{\infty}(u,y) = h_F(u,1,y)\) and \(f(x,y) = F(x^{-1}, y) \in \mathbb{K}[x^{-1}, y]\).

\(f(x,y) = x^{-n}F(x, y)\).
\(F\) has one place at infinity if, and only if, \(f(x,y)\) is irreducible in \(\mathbb{K}[x^{-1}, y]\).

Let us consider the hypothesis of the preposition and also that \(F\) has one place at the point at infinity. It is defined the numerical semigroup associated to \(f\) as
\[
\Gamma(f) = \{int(f,g) ~ | ~ g \in \mathbb{K}[x^{-1}][y] \setminus (f)\}.
\] It can be proven that \(\Gamma(f)\) is a subsemigroup of \(- \mathbb{N}\).

title: Exact degree of an algebroid curve
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial, and let \(x(t), y(t)\) a short parametrization of \(f\). Let \(\mathbf{A} = \mathbb{K}[[x(t), y(t)]]\) and let \(\mathbf{M} = x'(t) \mathbf{A} + y'(t) \mathbf{A}\). It is defined
\[
I = \{ord_t(g) ~ | ~ g \in \mathbf{M} \}.
\] It can be proven that \(I\) is a relative ideal of \(S = \Gamma(f)\), the numerical semigroup associated to f. It is said that \(i \in I\) is an exact degree if \(i+1 \in S\). The other elements are said non exact degrees of \(\mathbf{M}\). The set of non exact degrees is denoted by \(NE(M)\).

title: G-adic expansion
text:
Let \(F, G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\), with \(G \ne 0\). Let \(n = deg_y G\). Since in \(\mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) we have division algorithm, we can write \(F = QG + R\) where \(deg_y R < n\). If \(deg_y Q \ge n\), then write \(Q = Q^1 G + R^1\) with \(deg_y R^1 < n\). With this we can write \(F\) as \(F = Q^1 G^2 + R^1 G + R\). Then we restart with \(Q^1\). This process will stop giving the following expression in terms of the powers of \(G\):
\[
F = \sum_{k = 0}^l \alpha_k(x,y) G^k,
\]
where \(deg_y \alpha(x. y) < n\) for all \(k \in \{0, 1, \ldots, l\}\). It is defined the \(G-\)adic expansion of \(F\) as the previous expression of \(F\) in terms of \(G^k\).

title: G-adic expansion
text:
Let \(F, G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\), with \(G \ne 0\). Let \(n = deg_y G\). Since in \(\mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) we have division algorithm, we can write \(F = QG + R\) where \(deg_y R < n\). If \(deg_y Q \ge n\), then write \(Q = Q^1 G + R^1\) with \(deg_y R^1 < n\). With this we can write \(F\) as \(F = Q^1 G^2 + R^1 G + R\). Then we restart with \(Q^1\). This process will stop giving the following expression in terms of the powers of \(G\):
\[
F = \sum_{k = 0}^l \alpha_k(x,y) G^k,
\]
where \(deg_y \alpha(x. y) < n\) for all \(k \in \{0, 1, \ldots, l\}\). It is defined the \(G-\)adic expansion of \(F\) as the previous expression of \(F\) in terms of \(G^k\).

title: G-adic expansion
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(F = 3xy^4 + (6x + 1)y^3 + (6x^2 + 4x + 2)y^2 + (6x^2 + 2x + 3)y + 3x^3 + x^2 + x\) and \(G = y^2 + y + 1\). If we compute the first division,
\[
F(x,y) = [3xy^2 + (3x+1)y + (3x^2 + x + 1)]G + 2y = QG + R,
\]
and \(deg_y Q = 2 = deg_y G\). Repeating the process,
\[
Q = 3xG + (x + y + 1) = Q^1G + R^1,
\]
and \(deg_y Q^1 = 1 < deg_y G\). Therefore, the \(G-\)adic expansion of \(G\) is
\[
F = QG + R = (Q^1G + R^1)G + R = Q^1G^2 + R^1G + R
\]
\[
= 3xG^2 + (x + y + 1)G + 2y = \alpha_2(x,y)G^2 + \alpha_1(x,y)G + \alpha_0(x,y).
\]
\(\circ\) Let \(F = \sum_{k = 0}^l \alpha_k(x,y) G^k\). It can be proven by induction on \(l \in \mathbb{N}\) that the \(G-\)adic expression is unique.

title: Curve with one place at infinity
text: Let \(F = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x)\) be a nonzero polynomial of \(\mathbb{K}[x][y]\) and assume, possibly after a change of variables, that \(deg_x a_i < i\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\) such that \(a_i(x) \ne 0\). Let \(C = V(F)\) be the plane algebraic curve in \(\mathbb{A}_{\mathbb{K}}^2\) defined by \(F(x,y) = 0\), and let \(h_F(u,x,y) = u^nF(\frac{x}{u}, \frac{y}{u})\). The projective curve \(V(h_F)\) is the projective curve closure of \(C\) in \(\mathbb{P}_{\mathbb{K}}^2\). The embedding \(\mathbb{A}_{\mathbb{K}}^2 \subset \mathbb{P}_{\mathbb{K}}^2\) that send \((x,y) \to (u : x : y)\) has been used. By hypothesis on the coefficients of \(F\), \((0 : 1 : 0)\) is the unique point of \(V(h_F)\) at the line at infinity \(u = 0\). It is said that \(F\) has one place at infinity if \(h_F\) is analytically irreducible at \((0 : 1 : 0)\).

title: Newton-Puiseux exponents
text:
The definition of Newton-Puiseux exponents comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\). Suppose that \(f(x,y)\) is irreducible. There exists \(y(t) \in \mathbb{K}((t))\) such that \(f(t^n, y(t)) = 0\). Furthermore,

\(f(t^n, y) = \prod_{w, w^n = 1} (y - y(wt))\),
if \(w_1 \ne w_2\) and \(w_1^n = w_2^n = 1\), then \(y(w_1t) \ne y(w_2t)\),
\(gcd(n, gcd(Supp(y(t)))) = 1\),

where \(Supp(y(t))\) is the support of \(y(t)\).
Let us consider \(f(x,y) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) irreducible and let \(y = \sum_{p \in \mathbb{N}} c_p t^p \in \mathbb{K}((t))\).

Let \(d_1 = n = deg_y(f)\) and let \(m_1 = \min \{p \in Supp(y(t)) ~ | ~ d_1 \not | \ \ p\}\), \(d_2 = gcd(d_1, m_1)\). Then for all \(i \ge 2\), if \(d_i \ne 1\), let \(m_i = \min \{p \in Supp(y(t)) ~ | ~ d_i \not | \ \ p \}\) and \(d_{i+1} = gcd(d_i, m_i)\). By the above preposition, \(m_i\) is well defined and there exists \(h \ge 1\) such that \(d_{h+1} = 1\). It is defined the Newton-Poiseux exponents of \(f\) as \((m_1, m_2, \ldots, m_h)\) and is denoted by \(\underline{m}\).

title: Short parametrization
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial and \(S = \Gamma(f) = \langle r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_m \rangle\), with \(r_0 = n\) and \(r_0 = m\), where \(\Gamma(f)\) is the numerical semigroup associated to f and \(\underline{r} = (r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) comes from the definition of characteristic sequences of \(f\). Let \(C(f)\) be the algebroid curve \(f = 0\).
Let \(x(t) = t^n, y(t) = \sum_{p \ge m} c_p t^p\) be a parametrization of \(f\), and suppose, after a possibly a change of variables, that \(c_m = 1\). Suppose that \(y(t) - t^m \ne 0\). Let \(p_1 = \inf (Supp(y(t) - t^m)\), where \(Supp(y(t) - t^m)\) denotes the support of \(y(t) - t^m\). If \(p_1 \in S\), then \(p_1 = \sum_{i = 0}^h a_i r_i\) with \(a_0, \ldots, a_h \in \mathbb{N}\) and we consider the change of variables \(x_1 = x, y_1 = y - c_{p_1}x^{a_0}y^{a_1}G_2^{a_2}\cdots G_h^{a_h}\), where for all \(i \in \{1, \ldots, h\}\), \(G_i\) is an element of \(\mathbb{K}[[x, y]]\) such that \(int(f, G_i) = r_i\). It follows that \(f_1(x_1, y_1) = f(x_1, y_1 + c_{p_1}x^{a_0}y^{a_1}G_2^{a_2}\cdots G_h^{a_h})\) is an irreducible polynomial of \(\mathbb{K}[[x,y]]\) with parametrization \(x_1(t) = t^n, y_1(t) = t^m + \sum_{p > m} \tilde{c}_p t^p\) and either \(y_1(t) - t^m = 0\) or \(\inf (Supp(y_1(t) - t^m) > p_1\). In the second case, we restart with \(f_1, x_1(t), y_1(t)\). The conductor \(C(S)\) of \(S\) being finite, we get, after repeating the argument, the following:
Let us consider the hypothesis of the preposition. Then, modulo an automorphism of \(\mathbb{K}[[x,y]]\), \(f\) has a parametrization of the form \(x = t^n\) and \(y = t^m + \sum_{q \in G(S), q > m} c_q t^q\), where \(G(S)\) denotes the set of gaps of \(S\). It is said a short parametrization of \(C(f)\) an expression as above.

title: Left Elements
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number of \(S\). An element \(s \in \mathbb{N}\) is a left element (or small element) of \(S\) if \(s \in S\) and \(s < F(S)\). The set of left elements is denoted by \(N(S)\).
The set of left elements is always non-empty, due to \(0 \in N(S)\), and determines the numerical semigroup.

title: Left Elements
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number of \(S\). An element \(s \in \mathbb{N}\) is a left element (or small element) of \(S\) if \(s \in S\) and \(s < F(S)\). The set of left elements is denoted by \(N(S)\).
The set of left elements is always non-empty, due to \(0 \in N(S)\), and determines the numerical semigroup.

title: Left Elements
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 8, 10 \rangle\). We have that \(6 = 3 + 3 \in S\) and since \(8,9,10 \in S\), adding \(3\) to each number, we have that for \(n \ge 8\), it holds \(n \in S\) and \(7 \not \in S\), so the Frobenius number is \(F(S) = 7\) and the set of left elements is \(N(S) = \{0, 3, 6\}\).
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(b \in \mathbb{N}\) an odd integer arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \langle 2, b \rangle\). Note that for \(n \ge b-1\), it holds \(n \in S\) and \(b-2 \not \in S\), thus the Frobenius number is \(F(S) = b-2\) and the set of left elements is \(N(S) = \{0, 2, 4, \ldots, b-3\}\), in other words, the even elements between \(0\) and \(b-2\).

title: Embedding dimension
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is well known that every numerical semigroup admits a unique finite minimal system of generators \(B = \{n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_p\}\) for some \(p \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\). The embedding dimension is defined as the cardinal of the minimal system of generators, and it is denoted by \(e(S)\).

title: Embedding dimension
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is well known that every numerical semigroup admits a unique finite minimal system of generators \(B = \{n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_p\}\) for some \(p \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\). The embedding dimension is defined as the cardinal of the minimal system of generators, and it is denoted by \(e(S)\).

title: Embedding dimension
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \{0, 3, 6, 7, 9, 10, 12, \rightarrow\}\). First, we will compute the minimal system of generators of \(S\). The multiplicity of \(S\) is \(m(S) = 3\) and is always a minimal generator. On the other hand, the number \(7\) cannot be generated by \(3\), then \(7\) is another minimal generator. Considering the generators system \(B = \{3, 7\}\), we obtain \(S\), therefore, \(e(S) = |B| = 2\).
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(m \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \langle m, m+1, m+2, \ldots, 2m - 1 \rangle\). It is easy to see that \(B = \{m, m+1, m+2, \ldots, 2m - 1\}\) is a minimal system of generators of \(S\), therefore \(e(S) = m = m(S)\).

title: Semigroup ring
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(t\) be an indeterminant and \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field. It is defined the semigroup ring of \(S\) over \(\mathbb{K}\) as \(\mathbb{K}[t^s ~ | ~ s \in S] = \bigoplus_{s \in S} \mathbb{K}t^{s}\) and is denoted by \(\mathbb{K}[S]\). Note that \(\mathbb{K}[S]\) is a subring of the polynomial ring \(\mathbb{K}[t]\).

title: Semigroup ring
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(t\) be an indeterminant and \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field. It is defined the semigroup ring of \(S\) over \(\mathbb{K}\) as \(\mathbb{K}[t^s ~ | ~ s \in S] = \bigoplus_{s \in S} \mathbb{K}t^{s}\) and is denoted by \(\mathbb{K}[S]\). Note that \(\mathbb{K}[S]\) is a subring of the polynomial ring \(\mathbb{K}[t]\).

title: Semigroup ring
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(b \in \mathbb{N}\) an odd natural arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \langle 2, b \rangle\). It is easy to see that \(S = \{0, 2, 4, \ldots, b-1, b \rightarrow \}\), then \[
\mathbb{K}[S] = \{a_0 + a_1t^{s_1} + \cdots + a_nt^{s_n} ~ | ~ a_0, \ldots, a_n \in \mathbb{K}, s_0, s_1, \ldots, s_n \in S\}.
\] In this case, \(s_i\) is even or greater or equal to \(b\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\).

title: Pseudo Frobenius number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) is a pseudo-Frobenius number if \(x \not \in S\) and \(x + s \in S\) for all \(s \in S^*\). The set formed by the pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\) is denoted by \(PF(S)\).
The set \(PF(S)\) is always non-empty since \(F(S) \in PF(S)\), where \(F(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\). The cardinal of \(PF(S)\) is the type of \(S\).

title: Pseudo Frobenius number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) is a pseudo-Frobenius number if \(x \not \in S\) and \(x + s \in S\) for all \(s \in S^*\). The set formed by the pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\) is denoted by \(PF(S)\).
The set \(PF(S)\) is always non-empty since \(F(S) \in PF(S)\), where \(F(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\). The cardinal of \(PF(S)\) is the type of \(S\).

title: Pseudo Frobenius number
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 10 \rangle = \{0, 3, 5, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}\). The positive integers that do not belong to \(S\) are \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S = \{1, 2, 4, 7\}\), and as \(3 \in S\), the candidates for pseudo-Frobenius numbers belongs to the set \(\{-3, -2, -1, 1, 2, 4, 7 \}\). Checking the condition for each element, it is concluded that \(PF(S) = \{7\}\).
\(\circ\) The Frobenius number is the only pseudo-Frobenius number (the type is \(1\)) if, and only if, \(2g(S) = C(S)\), where \(g(S)\) is the genus of \(S\) and \(C(S)\) the conductor of \(S\).

title: Apéry Set
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(n \in S^*\). It is defined the Apéry set of \(S\) with respect to \(n\), denoted by \(Ap(S,n)\), to be the set
\[
Ap(S,n) = \{s \in S ~ | ~ s - n \not \in S\}.
\]
The knowledge of this set determines completely the numerical semigroup \(S\). \(Ap(S,n)\) always have \(n\) elements and it is easy to obtain the Frobenius number, the multiplicity and the genus of \(S\) from this set. This definition could be extended to the Apéry set of an integer.

title: Apéry Set
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(n \in S^*\). It is defined the Apéry set of \(S\) with respect to \(n\), denoted by \(Ap(S,n)\), to be the set
\[
Ap(S,n) = \{s \in S ~ | ~ s - n \not \in S\}.
\]
The knowledge of this set determines completely the numerical semigroup \(S\). \(Ap(S,n)\) always have \(n\) elements and it is easy to obtain the Frobenius number, the multiplicity and the genus of \(S\) from this set. This definition could be extended to the Apéry set of an integer.

title: Apéry Set
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 8, 10 \rangle\), or equivalently, \(S = \{0, 3, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}\), let’s compute the Apéry set of \(S\) with respect to \(n = 3\). All the elements greater or equal than \(11\) cannot be in the Apéry set. Indeed, the conductor of \(S\) is \(C(S) = 8\) and if \(n \ge 11\), \(n - 3 \ge 11 - 3 = 8\), in conclusion, \(n-3 \in S\). With the above reasoning, we have that \(Ap(S, 3) \subseteq \{0, 3, 6, 8, 9, 10\}\), and if we check the condition on each element, it is deduced that \(Ap(S,3) = \{0, 8, 10\}\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 6, 11, 13 \rangle\) and \(n = 6\). If we compute the first elements of \(S\), it is deduced that \(S = \{0, 4, 6, 8, 10, \rightarrow \}\) and \(C(S) = 10\), then if \(n \ge 16\), it holds \(n - 6 \in S\) and it must be \(Ap(S,6) \subseteq \{0, 4, 6, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15\}\). If we check on each number, it follows that \(Ap(S,6) = \{0, 4, 8, 11, 13, 15\}\).

title: Fundamental gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(G(S)\) be the set formed by the gaps of \(S\). A gap \(g \in G(S)\) is a fundamental gap of \(S\) if \(\{2g, 3g\} \subseteq S\), or equivalently, for every \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0,1\}\), it holds that \(ng \in S\). It is denoted by \(FG(S)\) the set of fundamental gaps of \(S\) and is always non-empty, due to \(F(S) \in FG(S)\), where \(F(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\).

title: Fundamental gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(G(S)\) be the set formed by the gaps of \(S\). A gap \(g \in G(S)\) is a fundamental gap of \(S\) if \(\{2g, 3g\} \subseteq S\), or equivalently, for every \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0,1\}\), it holds that \(ng \in S\). It is denoted by \(FG(S)\) the set of fundamental gaps of \(S\) and is always non-empty, due to \(F(S) \in FG(S)\), where \(F(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\).

title: Fundamental gap
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 10 \rangle = \{0, 4, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16, \rightarrow \}\). We have that \(G(S) = \{1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 11, 15\}\) and checking the condition for each gap of \(S\), it is concluded that \(FG(S) = \{6, 7, 11, 15\}\).
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(b \in \mathbb{N}\) an odd element arbitrary but fixed. The set \(S = \langle 2, b \rangle\) is a numerical semigroup (note that if \(n \ge b\), then \(n \in S\)) and the gaps of \(S\) are \(G(S) = \{1, 3, 5, 7, \ldots, b - 2\}\), in other words, all the odd naturals smaller than \(b\). Now, a gap \(x \in G(S)\) is fundamental if \(\{2x,3x\} \subseteq S\), in this case, as \(2 \in S\), then \(2x \in S\) for all \(x \in G(S)\). On the other hand, \(3x \in S\) if, and only if, \(x \ge \lceil \frac{b}{3} \rceil\), therefore, \(FG(S)\) consist in all the odd integers greater or equal to \(\lceil \frac{b}{3} \rceil\).

title: Degree of singularity
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(t\) be an indeterminant and \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field. As in the semigroup ring case, it is defined \(\mathbb{K}[[t^s ~ | ~ s \in S]]\), denoted by \(\mathbb{K}[[S]]\), and is a subring of the ring power series \(\mathbb{K}[[t]]\). It is defined the degree of singularity of \(\mathbb{K}[[S]]\) as the length of the \(\mathbb{K}[[S]]-\)module \(\mathbb{K}[[t]]/\mathbb{K}[[S]]\). Some authors use the terminology degree of singularity to refer the genus of a numerical semigroup.

title: Oversemigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup arbitrary but fixed. It is said that \(T\) is a oversemigroup of \(S\) if \(T\) is a numerical semigroup and \(S \subseteq T\). The set of oversemigroups of \(S\) is denoted by \(\mathcal{O}(S)\).
The set \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) is non-empty and finite for every numerical semigroup, since \(S \in \mathcal{O}(S)\) and \(|\mathbb{N} \setminus S|\) is finite.

title: Oversemigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup arbitrary but fixed. It is said that \(T\) is a oversemigroup of \(S\) if \(T\) is a numerical semigroup and \(S \subseteq T\). The set of oversemigroups of \(S\) is denoted by \(\mathcal{O}(S)\).
The set \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) is non-empty and finite for every numerical semigroup, since \(S \in \mathcal{O}(S)\) and \(|\mathbb{N} \setminus S|\) is finite.

title: Oversemigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 5, 6 \rangle = \{ 0, 4, 5, 6, 8, \rightarrow\}\). The gaps of \(S\) are \(G(S) = \{1, 2, 3, 7\}\), so to compute the oversemigroups we have to add gaps to \(S\) and check if it is in fact a numerical semigroup.

0 gaps: we have \(S \subseteq S\) so \(S\) is trivially a oversemigroup of \(S\).
1 gap: the candidates are \(T_{1,1} = S \cup \{1\}, T_{1,2} = S \cup \{2\}, T_{1,3} = S \cup \{3\}, T_{1,4} = S \cup \{7\}\) and \(T_4\) is the only numerical semigroup.
2 gaps: in this case the oversemigroups are \(T_{2,1} = S \cup \{2, 7\}, T_{2,2} = S \cup \{3, 7\}\).
3 gaps: the only oversemigroup is \(T_{3,1} = S \cup \{2, 3, 7\}\).
4 gaps: we have the trivial oversemigroup \(T_{4,1} = \mathbb{N}\).

To sum up, \(\mathcal{O}(S) = \{S, S \cup \{7\}, S \cup \{2, 7\}, S \cup \{3, 7\}, S \cup \{2, 3, 7\}, \mathbb{N}\}\).

title: Relation order of a numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the relation \(\le_S\) over \(\mathbb{Z}\) as follows:
\[
a \le_S b \Longleftrightarrow b - a \in S.
\] It is easy to prove that \(\le_S\) is a partial order relation. From this relation order is possible to characterize the pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\).

title: Relation order of a numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the relation \(\le_S\) over \(\mathbb{Z}\) as follows:
\[
a \le_S b \Longleftrightarrow b - a \in S.
\] It is easy to prove that \(\le_S\) is a partial order relation. From this relation order is possible to characterize the pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\).

title: Relation order of a numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 10, 14, 17, 21 \rangle\) and the integers \(x_1 = 8, x_2 = 62\). For \(x_1\), there is no positive integer \(y \ne x_1\) such that \(y \le_S x_1\), since \(x_1 - y = 8 - y < 10\) and the only element in \(S\) smaller than \(10\) is \(0\), therefore \(x_1\) is a minimal in \(\mathbb{N}\), but is not minimal in \(\mathbb{Z}\), since \(-2 \le_S x_1\). On the other hand, for \(x_2 = 62\) we have that \(10 \le_S 62\) and \(62 \le_S 72\).
\(\diamond\) Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number of \(S\). If we suppose \(F(S) \le_S x\) for some \(x \in \mathbb{Z} \setminus S\), then exists \(s \in S\) such that \(x = F(S) + y\), but that means \(x \in S\), which is a contradiction, therefore \(F(S)\) is maximal in \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus S\).

title: Special gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(PF(S)\) be the set of pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\). An element \(x \in PF(S)\) is a special gap if \(2x \in S\). The set of special gaps is denoted by \(SG(S)\) and is always non-empty, due to \(F(S) \in SG(S)\), where \(F(S)\) denotes the Frobenius number of \(S\). Its definition is motivated by the problem of finding the set of all numerical semigroups containing a given numerical semigroup.

title: Special gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(PF(S)\) be the set of pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\). An element \(x \in PF(S)\) is a special gap if \(2x \in S\). The set of special gaps is denoted by \(SG(S)\) and is always non-empty, due to \(F(S) \in SG(S)\), where \(F(S)\) denotes the Frobenius number of \(S\). Its definition is motivated by the problem of finding the set of all numerical semigroups containing a given numerical semigroup.

title: Special gap
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) a non-zero element arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \{0, m, \rightarrow \}\). Its easy to see that \(PF(S) = \{1,2, \ldots, m-1\}\), therefore an element \(n \in PF(S)\) is a special gap if \(2n \ge m\), that is, if \(n \ge \lceil \frac{m}{2} \rceil\), in conclusion, \(SG(S) = \{\lceil \frac{m}{2} \rceil, \lceil \frac{m}{2} \rceil + 1, \ldots, m-1 \}\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 10 \rangle = \{0, 3, 5, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}\). The positive integers that do not belong to \(S\) are \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S = \{1, 2, 4, 7\}\), and as \(3 \in S\), the candidates for pseudo-Frobenius numbers belongs to the set \(\{-3, -2, -1, 1, 2, 4, 7 \}\). Checking the condition for each element, it is concluded that \(PF(S) = \{7\}\) and \(SG(S) = \{7\}\).

title: Numerical Semigroup
text:
We say that \((S,+)\) is a numerical semigroup if \(S \subseteq \mathbb{N}\) and satisfies the following conditions:

For all \(a,b \in S\), then \(a + b \in S\).
\(0 \in S\).
The set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) is finite.

The first two conditions implies that \((S,+)\) is a submonoid of \((\mathbb{N}, +)\) and if there is no confusion, we denote the numerical semigroup as \(S\). The set formed by the non-zero elements of \(S\) is denoted by \(S^*\). Equivalently, \((S, +)\) is a numerical semigroup if \((S,+)\) is a submonoid of \((\mathbb{N}, +)\) and \(1 \in G\), where \(G = \{x - y ~ | ~ x,y \in S \}\).
As the complement is finite, there must be a \(c \in S\) such that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), \(c+n \in S\), this value \(c \in S\) is called the conductor of the semigroup and it is usually denoted by \(C(S)\). If \(s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n \in S\) are the elements smaller than the conductor (called left elements), then we write the numerical semigroup as \(S = \{0, s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n, C(S), \rightarrow \}\).

title: Numerical Semigroup
text:
We say that \((S,+)\) is a numerical semigroup if \(S \subseteq \mathbb{N}\) and satisfies the following conditions:

For all \(a,b \in S\), then \(a + b \in S\).
\(0 \in S\).
The set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) is finite.

The first two conditions implies that \((S,+)\) is a submonoid of \((\mathbb{N}, +)\) and if there is no confusion, we denote the numerical semigroup as \(S\). The set formed by the non-zero elements of \(S\) is denoted by \(S^*\). Equivalently, \((S, +)\) is a numerical semigroup if \((S,+)\) is a submonoid of \((\mathbb{N}, +)\) and \(1 \in G\), where \(G = \{x - y ~ | ~ x,y \in S \}\).
As the complement is finite, there must be a \(c \in S\) such that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), \(c+n \in S\), this value \(c \in S\) is called the conductor of the semigroup and it is usually denoted by \(C(S)\). If \(s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n \in S\) are the elements smaller than the conductor (called left elements), then we write the numerical semigroup as \(S = \{0, s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n, C(S), \rightarrow \}\).

title: Numerical Semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider a non-zero \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed. The set \(S = \mathbb{N} \setminus \{1, 2, \ldots, m-1\}\) is a numerical semigroup, and if we use the previous notation, \(S = \{0, m, \rightarrow \}\).
\(\circ\) Consider the submonoid generated by the set \(A = \{4,5\}\), that means, \(S = \langle 4, 5 \rangle\). Computing the first elements, we see that \(\{0, 4, 5, 8, 9, 10, 12\} \subseteq S\) and for any element \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) so that \(n \ge 12\), it holds \(n \in S\). In conclusion, \(S\) is a numerical semigroup and \(S = \{0, 4, 5, 8, 9, 10, 12 \rightarrow \}\).
\(\circ\) Consider the submonoid generated by the set \(A = \{5, 7, 11\}\), that means, \(S = \langle 5, 7, 11 \rangle\). If we compute the first elements, we obtain that \(\{0, 5, 7, 10, 11, 12, 14\} \subseteq S\) and the conductor is \(C(S) = 14\), therefore, \(S = \{0, 5, 7, 10, 11, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\).

title: Multiplicity
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. We say that \(s \in S\) is the multiplicity of \(S\) if it is the smallest non-zero element of \(S\), and it is denoted by \(m(S)\). Equivalently, the multiplicity of \(S\) is defined as the minimum of the minimal generator system of S.
As simple results, the multiplicity is an upper bound of the embedding dimension of \(S\), a minimal generator and does not determine the numerical semigroup.

title: Multiplicity
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. We say that \(s \in S\) is the multiplicity of \(S\) if it is the smallest non-zero element of \(S\), and it is denoted by \(m(S)\). Equivalently, the multiplicity of \(S\) is defined as the minimum of the minimal generator system of S.
As simple results, the multiplicity is an upper bound of the embedding dimension of \(S\), a minimal generator and does not determine the numerical semigroup.

title: Multiplicity
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider a non-zero \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \{0, m, \rightarrow\}\). Obviously \(m(S) = m\). This example shows that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), there exists a numerical semigroup \(S\) so that \(m(S) = n\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S_1 = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(S_2 = \{0, 5, \rightarrow\}\), obviously \(m(S_1) = 5 = m(S_2)\) and \(S_1 \ne S_2\).

title: Gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. By definition, the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) is finite, then it is said that a natural is a gap of \(S\) if it belongs to \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\). The set of gaps is usually denoted by \(G(S)\), and its cardinal, the genus of \(S\), by \(g(S)\). Note that the gaps determine completely the numerical semigroup. The maximum of \(G(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\).

title: Gap
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. By definition, the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) is finite, then it is said that a natural is a gap of \(S\) if it belongs to \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\). The set of gaps is usually denoted by \(G(S)\), and its cardinal, the genus of \(S\), by \(g(S)\). Note that the gaps determine completely the numerical semigroup. The maximum of \(G(S)\) is the Frobenius number of \(S\).

title: Gap
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 10 \rangle\). If we compute the first elements of \(S\), we arrive that \(S = \{0, 4, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16, \rightarrow \}\), then \(G(S) = \mathbb{N} \setminus S = \{1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 11, 15\}\).
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(b \in \mathbb{N}\) an odd element arbitrary but fixed. The set \(S = \langle 2, b \rangle\) is a numerical semigroup (note that if \(n \ge b\), then \(n \in S\)) and the gaps of \(S\) are \(G(S) = \{1, 3, 5, 7, \ldots, b - 2\}\), in other words, all the odd naturals smaller than \(b\).

title: Genus
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. By definition of numerical semigroup, the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\), usually denoted by \(G(S)\), is finite. It is defined the genus of \(S\) as the cardinal of the set \(|\mathbb{N} \setminus S|\), and it is denoted by \(g(S)\).
If \(n(S)\) is the cardinal of the set formed by the left elements of \(S\), and \(C(S)\) is the conductor of \(S\), it is deduced the relation \(n(S) + g(S) = C(S)\).

title: Genus
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. By definition of numerical semigroup, the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\), usually denoted by \(G(S)\), is finite. It is defined the genus of \(S\) as the cardinal of the set \(|\mathbb{N} \setminus S|\), and it is denoted by \(g(S)\).
If \(n(S)\) is the cardinal of the set formed by the left elements of \(S\), and \(C(S)\) is the conductor of \(S\), it is deduced the relation \(n(S) + g(S) = C(S)\).

title: Genus
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 6, 10, 13, 14, 15 \rangle\). Computing the first elements of \(S\), we can note that \(S = \{ 0, 6, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, \rightarrow \}\), and \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 17\}\), thus \(g(S) = 10\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \{ 0, 4, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13, 15, \rightarrow \}\). The set of left elements is \(N(S) = \{0, 4, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13\}\) and the conductor is \(C(S) = 15\), therefore \(g(S) = C(S) - n(S) = 15 - 7 = 8\).

title: Frobenius number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the Frobenius number of \(S\), denoted by \(F(S)\), as the maximum of the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\). Equivalently, the Frobenius number is the largest number that does not belong to \(S\) or the unique element in \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) so that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), we have that \(F(S) + n \in S\).
There is a obvious relation between the conductor and the Frobenius number, that is, \(F(S) + 1 = C(S)\). The Frobenius number does not determine in general the numerical semigroup, that means, it may exist more than one numerical semigroup with the same Frobenius number.

title: Frobenius number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the Frobenius number of \(S\), denoted by \(F(S)\), as the maximum of the set \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\). Equivalently, the Frobenius number is the largest number that does not belong to \(S\) or the unique element in \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S\) so that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), we have that \(F(S) + n \in S\).
There is a obvious relation between the conductor and the Frobenius number, that is, \(F(S) + 1 = C(S)\). The Frobenius number does not determine in general the numerical semigroup, that means, it may exist more than one numerical semigroup with the same Frobenius number.

title: Frobenius number
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider a non-zero \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \{0, m, \rightarrow\}\). Obviously, \(F(S) = m-1\) and in this case every element of \(S \setminus \{0\}\) is greater than the Frobenius number. This kind of numerical semigroups are the only ones that satisfy that property. This example shows that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), there exists a numerical semigroup \(S\) so that \(F(S) = n\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S_1 = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle\) and \(S_2 = \langle 2, 15 \rangle\). With simple calculations we obtain that \(S_1 = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(S_2 = \{0, 2,4,6,8,10,12,14, \rightarrow\}\), therefore \(F(S_1) = 13 = F(S_2)\) and \(S_1 \ne S_2\).

title: Frobenius number

title: Minimal set of generators
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(A \subset S\). We say that \(A\) is a minimal set of generators of \(S\) if \(S = \langle A \rangle\) and no proper subset of \(S\) has this property. It is well known that every numerical semigroup has a unique minimal set of generators, which is \(A = S^* \setminus (S^* + S^*)\).

title: Minimal set of generators
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(A \subset S\). We say that \(A\) is a minimal set of generators of \(S\) if \(S = \langle A \rangle\) and no proper subset of \(S\) has this property. It is well known that every numerical semigroup has a unique minimal set of generators, which is \(A = S^* \setminus (S^* + S^*)\).

title: Minimal set of generators
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 7, 12, 23 \rangle\). We have \(12 = 4 + 4 + 4\) and \(23 = 4 + 7 + 12\), so \(S = \langle 4, 7, 12, 23 \rangle = \langle 4, 7 \rangle\) and no proper subset of \(B = \{4,7\}\) generates \(S\), therefore, \(B\) is the set of minimal generators.
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 8, 9, 12, 15 \rangle\) and \(B = \{8, 9, 12, 15\}\). If we remove an element of \(B\), this cannot be generated, and as a consequence, no proper subset of \(B\) generates \(S\). In conclusion, \(B\) is already a minimal set of generators.

title: Conductor
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(s \in S\) is the conductor of \(S\) if for any \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), it satisfies that \(s + n \in S\), and it is denoted by \(C(S)\). Equivalently, \(s \in S\) is the conductor of \(S\) if for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(n \ge s\), it holds \(n \in S\).
There is a obvious relation between the conductor and the Frobenius number, that is, \(F(S) + 1 = C(S)\). The conductor does not determine in general the numerical semigroup, that means, it may exist more than one numerical semigroup with the same conductor.

title: Conductor
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is said that \(s \in S\) is the conductor of \(S\) if for any \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), it satisfies that \(s + n \in S\), and it is denoted by \(C(S)\). Equivalently, \(s \in S\) is the conductor of \(S\) if for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(n \ge s\), it holds \(n \in S\).
There is a obvious relation between the conductor and the Frobenius number, that is, \(F(S) + 1 = C(S)\). The conductor does not determine in general the numerical semigroup, that means, it may exist more than one numerical semigroup with the same conductor.

title: Conductor
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider a non-zero \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) arbitrary but fixed and \(S = \{0, m, \rightarrow\}\). Obviously, \(C(S) = m\) and in this case every element of \(S \setminus \{0\}\) is greater or equal than the conductor. This kind of numerical semigroups are the only ones that satisfy that property. This example shows that for any \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(n \ne 1\), there exists a numerical semigroup \(S\) such that \(C(S) = n\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S_1 = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle\) and \(S_2 = \langle 2, 15 \rangle\). With simple calculations we obtain that \(S_1 = \{0, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, \rightarrow \}\) and \(S_2 = \{0, 2,4,6,8,10,12,14, \rightarrow\}\), therefore \(C(S_1) = 14 = c(S_2)\) and \(S_1 \ne S_2\).

title: Type
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(PF(S)\) the set of pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\). The type of \(S\) is defined as the cardinal of the set \(PF(S)\).

title: Type
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(PF(S)\) the set of pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\). The type of \(S\) is defined as the cardinal of the set \(PF(S)\).

title: Type
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 6, 9, 13 \rangle = \{0, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, \rightarrow \}\), let’s compute the pseudo-Frobenius numbers of \(S\). The positive integers that do not belong to \(S\) are \(\mathbb{N} \setminus S = \{1,2,3,5,7,11\}\) and as \(4 \in S\), the candidates for pseudo-Frobenius numbers belongs to the set \(\{-4, -3, -2, -1, 1,2,3,5,7,11 \}\). Checking the condition of pseudo-Frobenius number on every candidate, it is conclude that \(PF(S) = \{11\}\) and \(t(S) = 1\).
\(\circ\) The type of a numerical semigroup is \(1\) if, and only if, \(2g(S) = C(S)\), where \(g(S)\) is the genus of \(S\) and \(C(S)\) the conductor of \(S\).

title: Set of divisors
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and an element \(x \in S\). It is defined the set of divisors of \(x\) in \(S\) as the set
\[
D(x) = \{s \in S ~ | ~ s \le_S x\},
\]
where \(\le_S\) is the relation order of \(S\). This set is always non-empty, since \(x \in D(x)\), and it is related with the notion of proper ideals of a numerical semigroup.

title: Set of divisors
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and an element \(x \in S\). It is defined the set of divisors of \(x\) in \(S\) as the set
\[
D(x) = \{s \in S ~ | ~ s \le_S x\},
\]
where \(\le_S\) is the relation order of \(S\). This set is always non-empty, since \(x \in D(x)\), and it is related with the notion of proper ideals of a numerical semigroup.

title: Set of divisors
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle = \{0, 3, 5, \rightarrow \}\) and \(x = 11\). Then, \(s \in D(11)\) if, and only if, \(11 - s \in S\). Checking the condition for every \(s \in S\) such that \(s \le 11\), it is obtained that \(D(11) = \{0, 3, 5, 6, 8, 11\}\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 10, 11 \rangle = \{0, 4, 8, \rightarrow \}\). For \(x = 4\), it is obtained \(D(4) = \{0, 4\}\), and for \(x = 8\), the set of divisors is \(D(8) = \{0, 4, 8\}\), then \(D(4) \subseteq D(8)\). In general, given \(x, y \in S\), it is deduced that \(D(x) \subseteq D(y)\) if, and only if, \(x \le_S y\). As \(\le_S\) is a partially relation order, the Hasse diagram can be constructed and given \(x \in S\), \(D(x)\) is the set formed by the elements \(y \in S\) such that there is a path from \(y\) to \(x\).

title: Intersection multiplicity
text:
The definition of Newton-Puiseux exponents comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\). Suppose that \(f(x,y)\) is irreducible. There exists \(y(t) \in \mathbb{K}((t))\) such that \(f(t^n, y(t)) = 0\).
Let \(f\) as in the preposition, \(g \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) with \(g \ne 0\) and \(y(t)\) a root of \(f(t^n, y(t)) = 0\). It is defined the intersection multiplicity of \(f\) with \(g\), denoted by \(int(f,g)\), to be
\[
int(f,g) = ord_t g(t^n, y(t))
\]
It can be proven that this definition does not depend on the root \(y(t)\), that is, \(int(f,g) = ord_t g(t^n, y(wt))\) for all \(w \in \mathbb{K}\) such that \(w^n = 1\).

title: Order
text:
Let \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field and \(x\) a variable. We denote by \(\mathbb{K}[[x]]\) the set of formal series on \(x\) with coefficients in \(\mathbb{K}\), that is, the set of elements of the form \(\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} a_i x^i\) with \(a_i \in \mathbb{K}\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\).
Let \(f(x) = \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} a_i x^i \in \mathbb{K}[[x]]\), it is defined the order of \(f\) as the smallest \(i \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(a_i \ne 0\), and it is denoted by \(ord_x(f(x))\). For \(f(x) = 0\), it is usually written \(ord_x(0) = + \infty\).

title: Order
text:
Let \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field and \(x\) a variable. We denote by \(\mathbb{K}[[x]]\) the set of formal series on \(x\) with coefficients in \(\mathbb{K}\), that is, the set of elements of the form \(\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} a_i x^i\) with \(a_i \in \mathbb{K}\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\).
Let \(f(x) = \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} a_i x^i \in \mathbb{K}[[x]]\), it is defined the order of \(f\) as the smallest \(i \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(a_i \ne 0\), and it is denoted by \(ord_x(f(x))\). For \(f(x) = 0\), it is usually written \(ord_x(0) = + \infty\).

title: Order
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(f(x) = 7x^5 + 4x^3 - x^2\). The coefficients are: \(a_0 = a_1 = 0, a_2 = -1, a_3 = 4, a_4 = 0\) and \(a_5 = 7\). The order of \(f(x)\) is \(2\) since \(a_0 = a_1 = 0\) and \(a_2 = -1 \ne 0\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let us consider \(f(x) = \sum_{s \in S \setminus \{0\}} x^s\). The order of \(f\) is the smallest non-zero coefficient, equivalent to compute the minimum of \(S^*\), which is the multiplicity of \(S\), \(m(S)\). Therefore, \(ord_x(f) = m(S)\).

title: Approximate root
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Let us consider \(d\) a divisor of \(n\) and let \(G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be a monic polynomial of degree \(\frac{n}{d}\) in \(y\). Let
\[
f = G^d + \alpha_1 G^{d-1} + \cdots + \alpha_d,
\]
be the G-adic expansion of \(f\). It is said that \(G\) is a \(d^{th}\) approximate root of \(f\) if \(\alpha_1 = 0\).
It can be proven that for any \(d\) divisor of \(n\), the \(d^{th}\) approximate root of \(f\) exists and it is unique. It is denoted by \(Ap(f;d)\).

title: Approximate root
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Let us consider \(d\) a divisor of \(n\) and let \(G \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be a monic polynomial of degree \(\frac{n}{d}\) in \(y\). Let
\[
f = G^d + \alpha_1 G^{d-1} + \cdots + \alpha_d,
\]
be the G-adic expansion of \(f\). It is said that \(G\) is a \(d^{th}\) approximate root of \(f\) if \(\alpha_1 = 0\).
It can be proven that for any \(d\) divisor of \(n\), the \(d^{th}\) approximate root of \(f\) exists and it is unique. It is denoted by \(Ap(f;d)\).

title: Approximate root
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(f = y^4 + 13x^2y^2 + 42x^2\), and \(d = 2\), let us calculate \(Ap(f, 2)\) applying an algorithm. First, let us consider \(G = y^{\frac{n}{d}} = y^2\) and compute the \(G-\)adic expansion of \(f\),
\[
f = y^4 + 13x^2y^2 + 42x^2 = G^2 + 13x^2G  + 42x^2
\]
We have \(\alpha_1(x,y) = 13x^2 \ne 0\), then, we consider now \(G_1 = T(G) = G + \frac{\alpha_1(x,y)}{d} = y^2 + \frac{13}{2}x^2\), where \(T(G)\) is the Tschirnhausen transform. If we compute the \(G_1-\)adic expansion of \(f\),
\[
f = G^2 + 13x^2G + 42x^2 = (G_1 - \frac{13}{2}x^2)^2 + 13x^2(G_1 - \frac{13}{2}x^2) + 42x^2
\] \[
= G_1^2 - 13x^2G_1 + \frac{169}{4}x^4 + 13x^2G_1 - \frac{169}{2}x^4 + 42x^2 = G_1^2 - \frac{169}{4}x^4 + 42x^2.
\] and \(\alpha_1(x,y) = 0\). To sum up, \(Ap(f,2) = y^2 + \frac{13}{2}x^2\).

title: Numerical semigroup associated to a polynomial
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. It is defined the numerical semigroup associated to a polynomial as
\[
\Gamma(f) = \{int(f,g) ~ | ~ g \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y] \setminus (f) \},
\]
where \(int(f,g)\) denotes the intersection multiplicity of \(f\) with \(g\).
It can be proven that for any polynomial \(f\) monic and irreducible in \(\mathbb{K}((x))[y]\), \(\Gamma(f)\) is a free numerical semigroup generated by \(\underline{r} = (r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\), where \(\underline{r}\) comes from the definition of characteristic sequences of \(f\).

title: Expansion
text:
Let \(g,G_1, \ldots, G_h \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) with \(G_1, \ldots, G_h\) non-zero and let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. The definition of expansion of \(g\) with respect to \((G_1, G_2, \ldots, G_h, f)\) comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(g,G_1, \ldots, G_h \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\), with \(G_1, \ldots, G_h\) non-zero and let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Then,
\[
g = \sum_{\theta \in \Theta} c_{\theta} (x) G_1^{\theta_1} G_2^{\theta_2} \cdots G_h^{\theta_h} f^{\theta_{h+1}},
\]
for some \(\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_{h+1}) \in \mathbb{N}^{h+1}\), with \(0 \le \theta_k < e_k\) for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\), where \((e_1, e_2, \ldots, e_h)\) comes from the definition of characteristic sequences of a formal series, and some \(c_{\theta} (x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))\). Moreover,
\[
deg_y g = \max \{c_{\theta} (x) G_1^{\theta_1} G_2^{\theta_2} \cdots G_h^{\theta_h} f^{\theta_{h+1}} ~ | ~ \theta \in \Theta \}.
\]
It is defined the expansion of \(g\) with respect to \((G_1, G_2, \ldots, G_h, f)\) as the expression of \(g\) obtained in the previous proposition.

title: Expansion
text:
Let \(g,G_1, \ldots, G_h \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) with \(G_1, \ldots, G_h\) non-zero and let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. The definition of expansion of \(g\) with respect to \((G_1, G_2, \ldots, G_h, f)\) comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(g,G_1, \ldots, G_h \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\), with \(G_1, \ldots, G_h\) non-zero and let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial. Then,
\[
g = \sum_{\theta \in \Theta} c_{\theta} (x) G_1^{\theta_1} G_2^{\theta_2} \cdots G_h^{\theta_h} f^{\theta_{h+1}},
\]
for some \(\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_{h+1}) \in \mathbb{N}^{h+1}\), with \(0 \le \theta_k < e_k\) for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\), where \((e_1, e_2, \ldots, e_h)\) comes from the definition of characteristic sequences of a formal series, and some \(c_{\theta} (x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))\). Moreover,
\[
deg_y g = \max \{c_{\theta} (x) G_1^{\theta_1} G_2^{\theta_2} \cdots G_h^{\theta_h} f^{\theta_{h+1}} ~ | ~ \theta \in \Theta \}.
\]
It is defined the expansion of \(g\) with respect to \((G_1, G_2, \ldots, G_h, f)\) as the expression of \(g\) obtained in the previous proposition.

title: Expansion
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(g = y^{10}\), and \(f = y^6 - 2x^2y^3 + x^4 - x^5y, G_1 = y, G_2 = y^3 - x^2\), let us compute the expansion of \(g\) with respect to \((G_1, G_2, f)\). If we divide \(g\) by \(f\),
\[
g = (2x^2y + y^4)f + (2x^7y^2 - 2x^6y + x^5y^5 + 3x^4y^4) = Qf + R.
\]
Since \(deg_y Q < deg_y f\), we start dividing \(Q\) and \(R\) by \(G_2\).
\[
Q = yG_2 + 3x^2y, \hspace{0.3cm} R = (x^5y^2 + 3x^4y)G_2 + 3x^7y^2 + x^6y.
\]
Finally,
\[
g = (yG_2 + 3x^2y)f + (x^5y^2 + 3x^4y)G_2 + 3x^7y^2 + x^6y
\]
\[
= G_1G_2f + 3x^2G_1f + x^5G_1^2G_2 + 3x^4G_1G_2 + 3x^7G_1^2 + x^6G_1.
\]

title: Pseudo-approximate root
text:
Let \(f(x,y) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) irreducible and \(y(t) = \sum_{p \in \mathbb{N}} c_p t^p \in \mathbb{K}((t))\) a root of \(f(t^n, y(t)) = 0\). Let \(\underline{m} = (m_0, m_1, \ldots, m_h)\), \(\underline{d} = (d_1, d_2, \ldots, d_{h+1})\) and \(\underline{r} = (r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) the characteristic sequences of \(f\).
Let \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\). Let \(\overline{y}(t) = \sum_{p < m_k} c_p t^p\) and let \(Y(t) = \overline{y}(t^{1/d_k}) \in \mathbb{K}((t))\). It is defined the \(d_k^{th}-\)pseudo-approximate root of \(f\) as
\[
G_k(t^{\frac{n}{d_k}}, y) = \prod_{v, v^{\frac{n}{d_k}} = 1} (y - Y(vt)).
\]

title: Pseudo-approximate root

\[

title: Contact
text:
The definition of contact needs the following result.
\(\textbf{Preposition}\): Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\). Suppose that \(f(x,y)\) is irreducible. Then, there exists \(y(t) \in \mathbb{K}((t))\) such that \(f(t^n, y(t)) = 0\) and there are finite polynomials satisfying this property.
Let \(f \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be a monic irreducible polynomial of degree \(n\) in \(y\) and \(y_1(t), \ldots, y_q(t)\) the roots of \(f(t^n, y) = 0\). Let \(g \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be another irreducible polynomial of degree \(p\) in \(y\), and let \(z_1(t), \ldots, z_p(t)\) be the set of roots of \(g(t^p, y) = 0\). It is defined the contact of \(f\) with \(g\) as
\[
c(f,g) = \frac{1}{np} \max_{i,j} ord_t (y_i(t^p) - z_j(t^n)).
\]

title: Contact
text:

title: Exact degree of a polynomial curve
text:
Let \(X(t) = t^n + \alpha_1t^{n-1} + \cdots + \alpha_n, Y(t) = t^m + \beta_1 t^{m-1} + \cdots + \beta_m\) be two polynomials of \(\mathbb{K}[t]\), and let \(\mathbf{A} = \mathbb{K}[X(t), Y(t)]\). Let \(\mathbf{M} = X'(t)\mathbf{A} + Y'(t)\mathbf{A}\). It is defined the set
\[
I = \{ord_t(F) ~ | ~ F \in \mathbf{M}\},
\] it can be proven that \(I\) is a relative ideal of \(S = \Gamma(f)\), where \(\Gamma(f)\) is the numerical semigroup associated to f. It is said that \(i \in I\) is an exact degree if \(i+1 \in S\). The other elements are said non exact degrees of \(\mathbf{M}\). The set of non exact degrees is denoted by \(NE(M)\).

title: Support
text:
Let \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field and \(t\) a variable. Let us consider \(y(t) = \sum_{p \in \mathbb{N}} c_p t^p \in \mathbb{K}((t))\). It is defined the support of \(y(t)\) as
\[
Supp(y(t)) = \{p ~ | ~ c_p \ne 0 \}.
\]

title: Support
text:
Let \(\mathbb{K}\) be a field and \(t\) a variable. Let us consider \(y(t) = \sum_{p \in \mathbb{N}} c_p t^p \in \mathbb{K}((t))\). It is defined the support of \(y(t)\) as
\[
Supp(y(t)) = \{p ~ | ~ c_p \ne 0 \}.
\]

title: Support
text:
Examples

\[
\mathbb{K}[t] = \{y(t) \in \mathbb{K}[[t]] ~ | ~ Supp(y(t)) < + \infty \} \subsetneq \mathbb{K}[[t]].
\]

title: Milnor number
text:
Let \(f(x,y) = y^n + a_1(x)y^{n-1} + \cdots + a_n(x) \in \mathbb{K}((x))[y]\) be an irreducible polynomial and let \(f_x, f_y\) the partial derivatives of \(f\). It is defined the Milnor number, denoted by \(\mu(f)\), as \(\mu(f) = int(f_x, f_y)\)
It can be proven that \(\int(f_x, f_y) = rank_{\mathbb{K}}(\mathbb{K}[[x]][y] / (f_x, f_y))\).

title: Free numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(B = \{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h\}\) be the set of minimal generators of \(S\). Let \(d_1 = r_0\) and for all \(k \in \{2, 3, \ldots, h+1\}\), set \(d_k = gcd(d_{k-1}, r_{k-1})\). Define \(e_k = \frac{d_k}{d_{k+1}}\) for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\). It is said that \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) if for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\):

\(e_k > 1\).
\(e_k r_k\) belongs to the semigroup generated by \(\{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_{k-1} \}\).

If \(S\) is free for all arrangements of its minimal generators, then it is said that \(S\) is universally free.

title: Free numerical semigroup
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(B = \{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h\}\) be the set of minimal generators of \(S\). Let \(d_1 = r_0\) and for all \(k \in \{2, 3, \ldots, h+1\}\), set \(d_k = gcd(d_{k-1}, r_{k-1})\). Define \(e_k = \frac{d_k}{d_{k+1}}\) for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\). It is said that \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) if for all \(k \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\):

\(e_k > 1\).
\(e_k r_k\) belongs to the semigroup generated by \(\{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_{k-1} \}\).

If \(S\) is free for all arrangements of its minimal generators, then it is said that \(S\) is universally free.

title: Free numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(a,b \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0, 1\}\) with \(gcd(a,b) = 1\) and \(S = \langle a,b \rangle\). Then, \(h = 1\), \(d_1 = a\) and \(d_2 = gcd(d_1, b) = 1\). We have, \(e_1 = a > 1\) and \(e_1 r_1 = ab \in \langle a \rangle\). Therefore, any numerical semigroup with embedding dimension two is free. In fact, they are telescopic numerical semigroups.
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 11 \rangle\). We have, \(d_1 = 4\), \(d_2 = gcd(4, 9) = 1\) and \(d_3 = gcd(1, 11) = 1\). On the other hand, \(e_1 = \frac{d_1}{d_2} = 4, e_2 = \frac{d_2}{d_3} = 1\). As \(e_2 \not > 1\), then \(S\) is not a free numerical semigroup.

title: Telescopic numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(B = \{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h\}\) the set of minimal generators of \(S\). It is said that \(S\) is telescopic if \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) and \(r_0 < r_1 < \cdots < r_h\).

title: Telescopic numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(B = \{r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h\}\) the set of minimal generators of \(S\). It is said that \(S\) is telescopic if \(S\) is free for the arrangement \((r_0, r_1, \ldots, r_h)\) and \(r_0 < r_1 < \cdots < r_h\).

title: Telescopic numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 6, 9 \rangle\). We have, \(h = 2, d_1 = 4, d_2 = 2\) and \(d_3 = 1\). Thus, \(e_1 = e_2 = 2\). As \(2 \cdot 6 \in \langle 4 \rangle\) and \(2 \cdot 9 \in \langle 4, 6 \rangle\), it is concluded that \(S\) is telescopic.
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 14 \rangle\) and the arrangement \(B_1 = \{14, 4, 9\}\). We have, \(d_1 = 14, d_2 = gcd(14, 4) = 2\) and \(d_3 = gcd(2, 9) = 1\). Moreover, \(e_1 = \frac{d_1}{d_2} = 7 > 1, e_2 = \frac{d_2}{d_3} = 2 > 1\), \(e_1r_1 = 7 \cdot 4 \in \langle 14 \rangle\) and \(e_2r_2 = 2 \cdot 9 \in \langle 14, 4 \rangle\), therefore \(S\) is free for the arrangement \(B_1\). If we check with the arrangement \(B_2 = \{4, 9, 14\}\), is is obtained that \(d_1 = 4, d_2 = gcd(4, 9) = 1, d_3 = 1\) and \(e_2 = \frac{d_2}{d_3} = 1 \not > 1\), therefore \(S\) is not telescopic.

title: Pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup
text: A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be pseudo-symmetric if it is irreducible and its Frobenius number is even.

title: Pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup
text: A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be pseudo-symmetric if it is irreducible and its Frobenius number is even.

title: Pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 10, 17 \rangle\). This numerical semigroup is irreducible and if we compute the first elements of \(S\), we obtain that \(S = \{0, 4, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 22, 24, \rightarrow \}\), so \(F(S) = 23\) and \(S\) is not a pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup. The irreducible numerical semigroups with odd Frobenius number are called symmetric numerical semigroups.

title: Pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup
Pseudo-symmetric numerical semigroup
