title: Irreducible numerical semigroup
text:
A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the intersection of two numerical semigroups properly containing it.
It is well known that the intersection of two numerical semigroups is also a numerical semigroup.

title: Irreducible numerical semigroup
text:
A numerical semigroup \(S\) is said to be irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the intersection of two numerical semigroups properly containing it.
It is well known that the intersection of two numerical semigroups is also a numerical semigroup.

title: Irreducible numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 5, 7, 9 \rangle\) and the numerical semigroups \(S_1 = \langle 5, 7, 8, 9 \rangle\) and \(S_2 = \langle 5, 7, 9, 11 \rangle\). Clearly, \(S \subsetneq S_1\), \(S \subsetneq S_2\) and \(S = S_1 \cap S_2\), since \(S_1 = S \cup \{8, 13\}\) and \(S_2 = S \cup \{11\}\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 2, 7 \rangle = \{0, 2, 4, 6, \rightarrow \}\), let’s prove that \(S\) is irreducible. Let us consider the set of oversemigroups of \(S\),
\[
\mathcal{O}(S) = \{\mathbb{N}, \{0, 2, \rightarrow\}, \{0, 2, 4, \rightarrow\}, S\} = \{\mathbb{N}, S \cup \{3, 5\}, S \cup \{5\}, S\} = \{\mathbb{N}, T_1, T_2, S\}.
\] If \(S\) is not irreducible, the only possibility is \(S = T_1 \cap T_2\), but \(T_1 \cap T_2 = S \cup \{5\} \ne S\), therefore \(S\) is irreducible.

title: Irreducible numerical semigroup
Irreducible numerical semigroup
text: References

title: Arf closure
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) the set of oversemigroups of \(S\). It is defined the Arf closure as the smallest Arf numerical semigroup containing \(S\).
It can be proven that the intersection of Arf semigroups is also an Arf semigroup, from that it is deduced that the Arf closure is the intersection of all Arf numerical semigroups containing it, and since \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) is finite, the intersection is also finite.

title: Arf closure
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) the set of oversemigroups of \(S\). It is defined the Arf closure as the smallest Arf numerical semigroup containing \(S\).
It can be proven that the intersection of Arf semigroups is also an Arf semigroup, from that it is deduced that the Arf closure is the intersection of all Arf numerical semigroups containing it, and since \(\mathcal{O}(S)\) is finite, the intersection is also finite.

title: Arf closure
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 6, 9 \rangle = \{0, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, \rightarrow \}\). The set of oversemigroups is
\[
\mathcal{O}(S) = \{\mathbb{N}, \{0, 2, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 2, 4, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 2, 4, 6, \rightarrow\}, \{0, 2, 4, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 3, \rightarrow \},
\]
\[
\{0, 3, 4, 6, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 4, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 4, 5, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 4, 6, \rightarrow \}, \{0, 4, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}, S \}.
\]
Moreover, the Arf semigroups are
\[
T_0 = \mathbb{N}, T_1 = \{0, 2, \rightarrow \}, T_2 = \{0, 2, 4, \rightarrow \}, T_3 = \{0, 2, 4, 6, \rightarrow \}, T_4 = \{0, 2, 4, 6, 8, \rightarrow \},
\]
\[
T_5 = \{0, 3, \rightarrow \}, T_6 = \{0, 4, \rightarrow \}, T_7 = \{0, 4, 6, \rightarrow \}, T_8 = \{0, 4, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}.
\]
Therefore, the Arf closure of \(S\) is \(A = \bigcap_{i = 0}^8 T_i = \{0, 4, 6, 8, \rightarrow \} = S \cup \{11\}\). In this case, the Arf closure of \(S\) is the numerical semigroup \(S\) to which its Frobenius number has been added.

title: Arf closure
Arf closure

title: Maximal ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the maximal ideal of \(S\) as the subset \(S^*\), and is denoted by \(M(S)\). This definition is motivated by the definitions relative ideal of \(S\) and proper ideal of \(S\).

title: Maximal ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. It is defined the maximal ideal of \(S\) as the subset \(S^*\), and is denoted by \(M(S)\). This definition is motivated by the definitions relative ideal of \(S\) and proper ideal of \(S\).

title: Maximal ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a proper ideal of \(S\). By definition, \(E \subseteq S\), and if \(0 \in E\), then \(S \subseteq S + E\), but if \(E\) is a proper ideal of \(S\), \(S + E \subseteq E\), therefore \(E = S\). In conclusion, every proper ideal of \(S\) is a subset of \(S^*\).

title: Maximal ideal
Maximal ideal
text: References

title: Relative ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. A subset \(E\) of \(\mathbb{Z}\) is a relative ideal of \(S\) if \(S + E = \{s + e ~ | ~ s \in S, e \in E \} \subseteq E\) and there exists \(s \in S\) such that \(s + E = \{s + e ~ | ~ e \in E \}\subseteq S\).
Two relative ideals \(E\) and \(H\) are said to be equivalent if there exists \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(E = x + H = \{x + h ~ | ~ h \in H \}\). As a consequence, every relative ideal is equivalent to some proper ideal.

title: Relative ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup. A subset \(E\) of \(\mathbb{Z}\) is a relative ideal of \(S\) if \(S + E = \{s + e ~ | ~ s \in S, e \in E \} \subseteq E\) and there exists \(s \in S\) such that \(s + E = \{s + e ~ | ~ e \in E \}\subseteq S\).
Two relative ideals \(E\) and \(H\) are said to be equivalent if there exists \(x \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(E = x + H = \{x + h ~ | ~ h \in H \}\). As a consequence, every relative ideal is equivalent to some proper ideal.

title: Relative ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 8, 10 \rangle = \{0, 3, 6, 8, \rightarrow \}\) and \(E = \langle 3 \rangle\) the ideal generated by \(A = \{3\}\) in \(\mathbb{Z}\). \(E\) is not a relative ideal since \(S + E \subsetneq E\), note that \(3 + 8 = 11 \not \in E\) but \(3 \in E\) and \(8 \in S\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup, \(k \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) and \(I = \{i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k\}\) a subset of \(\mathbb{Z}\) arbitrary but fixed. Then, the set \(E = I + S\) is a relative ideal of \(S\). The first condition is obvious, and if we take \(w = \min \{0, i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k\}\), defining \(s = C(S) - w\), where \(C(S)\) denotes the conductor of \(S\), we have that \(s + E \subseteq S\). In conclusion, \(E\) is a relative ideal.

title: Z-irreducible ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is \(\mathbb{Z}\) irreducible if it cannot be expressed as a finite intersection of other relative ideals properly containing it.
It can be proven that every relative ideal has a unique finite factorization in \(\mathbb{Z}-\)irreducible components, they are called as the \(\mathbb{Z}-\)irreducible components of \(E\).

title: Z-irreducible ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is said that \(E\) is \(\mathbb{Z}\) irreducible if it cannot be expressed as a finite intersection of other relative ideals properly containing it.
It can be proven that every relative ideal has a unique finite factorization in \(\mathbb{Z}-\)irreducible components, they are called as the \(\mathbb{Z}-\)irreducible components of \(E\).

title: Z-irreducible ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\), \(I = \{4, 5\}\) and \(E = I + S\). Making simple calculations, \(F(S) = 4\) and \(K(S) = \{0, 2, 3, 5, \rightarrow \}\), where \(K(S)\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\). We have that \(E = (-2 + K(S)) \cap (2 + K(S))\). Indeed,
\[
(-2 + K(S)) \cap (2 + K(S)) = \{-2, 0, 1, 3, \rightarrow \} \cap \{2, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow\}
\]
\[
= \{4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \} = \{4, 5\} + S = E.
\]
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup with Frobenius number \(F(S)\), \(K(S)\) the standard canonical ideal and \(E\) a canonical ideal of \(S\) with Frobenius number ideal \(F(E)\). If \(E\) is a canonical ideal, \(\tilde{E} = K\), where \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\).
Let’s suppose that exist \(K_1, K_2, \ldots, K_h\) relative ideals such that \(E \subseteq K_i\) for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\) and \(E = K_1 \cap K_2 \cap \ldots \cap K_h\). Then, exist \(j \in \{1, 2, \ldots, h\}\) so that \(F(E) \not \in K_j\) and \(\{F(E) + 1, \rightarrow \} \subseteq K_j\), therefore \(F(K_j) = F(E)\). If \(E \subset K_j\), then \(K(S) = \tilde{E} \subseteq \tilde{K_j}\), but it is known that for any relative ideal, \(\tilde{K_j} \subseteq K(S) = \tilde{E}\). To conclude, we have \(\tilde{E} = \tilde{K_j}\), that means \(E = K_j\) and \(E\) is \(\mathbb{Z}-\)irreducible.

title: Multiplicity sequence
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(M = S^*\) the maximal ideal of \(S\) and \(\mathcal{B}(M)\) the blowup of \(M\). It is known that \(\mathcal{B}(M)\) is a numerical semigroup such that \(S \subseteq \mathcal{B}(M)\), then, setting \(S^1 = \mathcal{B}(M)\), it can be considered the blowup of its maximal ideal, \(S^2\), and repeating the argument, it is obtained a chain of numerical semigroups
\[
S = S^0 \subseteq S^1 \subseteq S^2 \subseteq \cdots \subseteq S^i \subseteq S^{i+1} \subseteq\cdots
\]
where \(S^{i+1}\) is the blowup of the maximal ideal of \(S^i\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\). This chain stabilizes at \(\mathbb{N}\), and if we consider the multiplicity \(m_i = m(S^i)\) of each \(S^i\), we get a non increasing sequence \((m_0, m_1, m_2, \ldots)\) that stabilizes at \(1\). It is defined the multiplicity sequence of \(S\) as the sequence \((m_0, m_1, m_2, \ldots)\).

title: Multiplicity sequence
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, \(M = S^*\) the maximal ideal of \(S\) and \(\mathcal{B}(M)\) the blowup of \(M\). It is known that \(\mathcal{B}(M)\) is a numerical semigroup such that \(S \subseteq \mathcal{B}(M)\), then, setting \(S^1 = \mathcal{B}(M)\), it can be considered the blowup of its maximal ideal, \(S^2\), and repeating the argument, it is obtained a chain of numerical semigroups
\[
S = S^0 \subseteq S^1 \subseteq S^2 \subseteq \cdots \subseteq S^i \subseteq S^{i+1} \subseteq\cdots
\]
where \(S^{i+1}\) is the blowup of the maximal ideal of \(S^i\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\). This chain stabilizes at \(\mathbb{N}\), and if we consider the multiplicity \(m_i = m(S^i)\) of each \(S^i\), we get a non increasing sequence \((m_0, m_1, m_2, \ldots)\) that stabilizes at \(1\). It is defined the multiplicity sequence of \(S\) as the sequence \((m_0, m_1, m_2, \ldots)\).

title: Multiplicity sequence
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\). We have \(m(S) = 3\) and \(S^*\) has reduction number \(r(S^*) = 1\), since
\[
2S^* = S^* + S^* = \{6, 8, \rightarrow \} = 3 + S^* = m(S) + S^*.
\] Then, \(S^1 = \mathcal{B}(S^*) = S^* - S^* = \{0, 2, \rightarrow \}\). Now, \(m(S^1) = 2\) and \(r((S^1)^*) = 1\),
\[
2(S^1)^* = (S^1)^* + (S^1)^* = \{4, \rightarrow \} = 2 + (S^1)^*.
\]
Finally, \(S^2 = \mathcal{B}((S^1)^*) = (S^1)^* - (S^1)^* = \mathbb{N}\) and the multiplicity sequence of \(S\) is \((3,2,1)\).

title: Multiplicity of an ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the multiplicity of \(E\) as the minimum of \(E\).
It can be proven that every relative ideal of a semigroup has a minimum. This property is due to the second condition of relative ideal of a numerical semigroup.

title: Multiplicity of an ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). It is defined the multiplicity of \(E\) as the minimum of \(E\).
It can be proven that every relative ideal of a semigroup has a minimum. This property is due to the second condition of relative ideal of a numerical semigroup.

title: Multiplicity of an ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(E = \{-2, -1\} + S\). Clearly, \(S + E \subseteq S\) and if we take \(s = C(S) + 2\), where \(C(S)\) is the conductor of \(S\) then \(s + E \subseteq S\), therefore \(E\) is a relative ideal of \(S\) and \(m(E) = -2\).

title: Reduction number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with multiplicity \(m(E)\). It is defined the reduction number of \(E\), denoted by \(r(E)\), as the value
\[
r(E) = \min \{h \ge 1 ~ | ~ (h+1)E = m(E) + hE \}.
\]
A proper ideal is said to be stable if \(r(E) = 1\), that is, \(2E = m(E) + E\).

title: Reduction number
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a proper ideal of \(S\) with multiplicity \(m(E)\). It is defined the reduction number of \(E\), denoted by \(r(E)\), as the value
\[
r(E) = \min \{h \ge 1 ~ | ~ (h+1)E = m(E) + hE \}.
\]
A proper ideal is said to be stable if \(r(E) = 1\), that is, \(2E = m(E) + E\).

title: Reduction number
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\), \(I = \{2, 4\}\) and \(E = I + S = \{2, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \}\). Clearly, \(m(E) = 2\), then we are looking for the smaller \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) such that \((h+1)E = 2 + hE\). If we take \(h = 1\),
\[
2E = E + E = \{4, 6, \rightarrow\} \ne \{4, 6, 7, 9, \rightarrow \} = 2 + E.
\]
For \(h = 2\),
\[
3E = (E + E) + E = \{6, 8, \rightarrow\} = 2 + 2E
\]
To sum up, \(r(E) = 2\).

title: Proper ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a subset of \(\mathbb{Z}\). It is said that \(E\) is a proper ideal of \(S\), or simply an ideal of \(S\), if \(E\) is a relative ideal of \(S\) and \(E \subseteq S\).

title: Proper ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a subset of \(\mathbb{Z}\). It is said that \(E\) is a proper ideal of \(S\), or simply an ideal of \(S\), if \(E\) is a relative ideal of \(S\) and \(E \subseteq S\).

title: Proper ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let’s prove that \(E = S^*\) is an ideal of \(S\). Clearly \(S^* \subseteq S\) and \(S + S^* \subseteq S^*\). If we consider \(s = C(S)\), where \(C(S)\) denotes the conductor of \(S\), we have \(C(S) + S^* \subseteq S\), therefore \(S^*\) is an ideal. The ideal \(S^*\) is called the maximal ideal of \(S\).
\(\circ\) Let \(b \in \mathbb{N}\) an odd natural arbitrary but fixed, \(S = \langle 2, b \rangle = \{0, 2, 4, \ldots, b - 1\}\) and \(E = \{0, b, \rightarrow \}\). Clearly, \(E\) is an ideal of \(S\). In general, given a numerical semigroup \(S\), the set \(E = \{C(S), \rightarrow\}\) is a proper ideal and is called the conductor ideal of \(S\).

title: Proper ideal
Proper ideal

title: Reduction
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(H,E\) two proper ideals of \(S\) with \(H \subseteq E\). We say that \(H\) is a reduction of \(E\) if, for some \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), the equality \((h+1)E = H + hE\) holds.

title: Reduction
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(H,E\) two proper ideals of \(S\) with \(H \subseteq E\). We say that \(H\) is a reduction of \(E\) if, for some \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\), the equality \((h+1)E = H + hE\) holds.

title: Reduction
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a proper ideal of \(S\) with multiplicity \(m(E)\). If we consider the following chain of relative ideals,
\[
S \subseteq E - m(E) \subseteq 2E - 2m(E) \subseteq \cdots \subseteq jE - jm(E) \subseteq \cdots \subseteq \mathbb{N},
\]
it eventually stabilizes, since \(|\mathbb{N} \setminus S|\) is finite. Then, exists \(h \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}\) such that \(hE - hm(E) = (h+1)E - (h+1)m(E)\), or equivalently, \((h+1)E = hE + m(E) = [m(E) + S] + hE\), that means, \(m(E) + S\) is a reduction of \(E\).

title: Frobenius number of an ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a relative ideal of \(S\). The Frobenius number of \(E\) is defined as the maximum of the set \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus E\), and it is denoted as \(F(E)\).
It is easy to prove from the definition of relative ideal that the set \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus E\) always has a maximum. Unlike the Frobenius number of a numerical semigroup, \(F(E)\) can be negative.

title: Frobenius number of an ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a relative ideal of \(S\). The Frobenius number of \(E\) is defined as the maximum of the set \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus E\), and it is denoted as \(F(E)\).
It is easy to prove from the definition of relative ideal that the set \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus E\) always has a maximum. Unlike the Frobenius number of a numerical semigroup, \(F(E)\) can be negative.

title: Frobenius number of an ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup, \(F(S)\) its Frobenius number and \(E\) a relative ideal of \(S\). If we define \(\tilde{E} = E + (F(S) - F(E))\), then the maximum of the set \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus \tilde{E}\) is the maximum of \(\mathbb{Z} \setminus E\) adding \(F(S) - F(E)\), that means, \(F(\tilde{E}) = F(E) + F(S) - F(E) = F(S)\). To sum up, every relative ideal \(E\) of \(S\) is equivalent (see definition of equivalence of relative ideals) to a relative ideal with same Frobenius number as \(S\).
\(\circ\) Let \(S\) a numerical semigroup, \(F(S)\) its Frobenius number and \(K(S)\) its standard canonical ideal. Recall that \(x \in K(S)\) if, and only if, \(F(S) - x \not \in S\), thus \(F(S) \not \in K(S)\). Furthermore, if \(x > F(S)\), \(F(S) - x < 0\) and \(x \in K(S)\), in conclusion, \(F(K(S)) = F(S)\).

title: Frobenius number of an ideal
Frobenius number of an ideal

title: Canonical ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with Frobenius number \(F(S)\) and \(E\) a relative ideal with Frobenius number of the ideal \(F(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is a canonical ideal if \(\tilde{E} = K(S)\), where \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\) and \(K(S)\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\).

title: Canonical ideal
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with Frobenius number \(F(S)\) and \(E\) a relative ideal with Frobenius number of the ideal \(F(E)\). It is said that \(E\) is a canonical ideal if \(\tilde{E} = K(S)\), where \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E)\) and \(K(S)\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\).

title: Canonical ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 5, 7 \rangle = \{0, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \}\) and \(E = \{-15, -12, -11, -10, -8\} + S\). It is easy to check that \(F(S) = 6\), \(F(E) = -9\) and \(K(S) = \{0, 3, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \}\), then \(\tilde{E} = E + F(S) - F(E) = E + 15\). If \(F(E) = -9\), \(E = \{-15, -12, -11, -10, -8, \rightarrow\}\), so \(\tilde{E} = \{0, 3, 4, 5, 7\} + S = K(S)\) and \(E\) is a canonical ideal.

title: Canonical ideal
Canonical ideal

title: Standard canonical ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number of \(S\). The standard canonical ideal of \(S\) is defined as
\[
K(S) = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ F(S) - x \not \in S\}.
\]
It can be proven that the standard canonical ideal is a relative ideal of \(S\) and \(S \subseteq K(S) \subseteq \mathbb{N}\).

title: Standard canonical ideal
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(F(S)\) the Frobenius number of \(S\). The standard canonical ideal of \(S\) is defined as
\[
K(S) = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ F(S) - x \not \in S\}.
\]
It can be proven that the standard canonical ideal is a relative ideal of \(S\) and \(S \subseteq K(S) \subseteq \mathbb{N}\).

title: Standard canonical ideal
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 4, 9, 10 \rangle = \{0, 4, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16, \rightarrow \}\). The Frobenius number of \(S\) is \(F(S) = 15\), thus \(K(S) = \{x \in \mathbb{Z} ~ | ~ 15 - x \not \in S\}\). The set of gaps of \(S\) is \(G(S) = \{1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 11, 15\}\), then if we compute \(15 -g\) for every \(g \in G(S)\), we have that \(K(S) = S \cup \{4, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14\} = \{0, 4, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16, \rightarrow \} = S\). It can be proven that \(S = K(S)\) if, and only if, \(S\) is symmetric.

title: Irreducible Z-components
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a relative ideal of \(S\). The definition of irreducible \(\mathbb{Z}-\)components of a relative ideal comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Proposition}\): Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). Let \(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_h\) be the minimal generators of the ideal \(K - E\). Then,
\[
E = (-x_1 + K) \cap \cdots \cap (-x_h + K),
\]
where \(K\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\). This decomposition is irredundant an unique.
It is defined the irreducible \(\mathbb{Z}-\)components as the ideals \(-x_i + K\) that generates the factorization.

title: Irreducible Z-components
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and \(E\) a relative ideal of \(S\). The definition of irreducible \(\mathbb{Z}-\)components of a relative ideal comes from the following result.
\(\textbf{Proposition}\): Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup and let \(E\) be a relative ideal of \(S\). Let \(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_h\) be the minimal generators of the ideal \(K - E\). Then,
\[
E = (-x_1 + K) \cap \cdots \cap (-x_h + K),
\]
where \(K\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\). This decomposition is irredundant an unique.
It is defined the irreducible \(\mathbb{Z}-\)components as the ideals \(-x_i + K\) that generates the factorization.

title: Irreducible Z-components
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 3, 5, 7 \rangle\), \(I = \{4, 5\}\) and \(E = I + S\). Making simple calculations, \(F(S) = 4\) and \(K(S) = \{0, 2, 3, 5, \rightarrow \}\), where \(K(S)\) denotes the standard canonical ideal of \(S\). We have that \(E = (-2 + K(S)) \cap (2 + K(S))\). Indeed,
\[
(-2 + K(S)) \cap (2 + K(S)) = \{-2, 0, 1, 3, \rightarrow \} \cap \{2, 4, 5, 7, \rightarrow\}
\]
\[
= \{4, 5, 7, \rightarrow \} = \{4, 5\} + S = E.
\]

title: Factorization homomorphism
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with minimal set of generators by \(\{n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_p\}\). It is defined the factorization homomorphism of \(S\) as the application \(\phi\) such that
\[
\phi: \mathbb{N}^p \to S ~ ; ~ \phi(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_p) = \sum_{i = 1}^p a_i n_i.
\] It can be proven that \(\phi\) is a monoid epimorphism, and consequently \(S\) is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{N}^p / \ker(\phi)\), where \(\ker(\phi)\) is the kernel congruence of \(\phi\):
\[
\ker(\phi) = \{(a, b) \in \mathbb{N}^p \times \mathbb{N}^p ~ | ~ \phi(a) = \phi(b)\}.
\]

title: Factorization homomorphism
text:
Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup with minimal set of generators by \(\{n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_p\}\). It is defined the factorization homomorphism of \(S\) as the application \(\phi\) such that
\[
\phi: \mathbb{N}^p \to S ~ ; ~ \phi(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_p) = \sum_{i = 1}^p a_i n_i.
\] It can be proven that \(\phi\) is a monoid epimorphism, and consequently \(S\) is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{N}^p / \ker(\phi)\), where \(\ker(\phi)\) is the kernel congruence of \(\phi\):
\[
\ker(\phi) = \{(a, b) \in \mathbb{N}^p \times \mathbb{N}^p ~ | ~ \phi(a) = \phi(b)\}.
\]

title: Factorization homomorphism
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let \(S = \langle 10, 17, 21 \rangle\). The factorization homomorphism of \(S\) is defined as
\[
\phi: \mathbb{N}^3 \to S ~ ; ~ (a_1, a_2, a_3) \to 10a_1 + 17a_2 + 21a_3.
\]
Minimal generators only have a single preimage by definition of minimal set of generators, which is \(n_i = \phi(e^i)\) with \(e_i^i = 1\) and \(e_i^j = 0\) for all \(j \ne i\). Furthermore, there are always elements with more than one preimage, for example \(68 = 10 \cdot 0 + 17 \cdot 4 + 21 \cdot 0 = \phi(0, 4, 0)\) and \(68 = 10 \cdot 3 + 17 \cdot 1 + 21 \cdot 1 = \phi(3,1,1)\).

title: Presentation of a numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, let \(\phi\) be the factorization homomorphism of \(S\) and let \(\ker(\phi)\) be the kernel of \(\phi\) as a congruence. A set \(B \subseteq \ker(\phi)\) is a presentation of \(S\) if \(B\) is a generator system of \(\ker(\phi)\). It is said that \(B\) is a minimal presentation if no proper subsets of \(B\) is a presentation.

title: Presentation of a numerical semigroup
text: Let \(S\) be a numerical semigroup, let \(\phi\) be the factorization homomorphism of \(S\) and let \(\ker(\phi)\) be the kernel of \(\phi\) as a congruence. A set \(B \subseteq \ker(\phi)\) is a presentation of \(S\) if \(B\) is a generator system of \(\ker(\phi)\). It is said that \(B\) is a minimal presentation if no proper subsets of \(B\) is a presentation.

title: Presentation of a numerical semigroup
text:
Examples
\(\circ\) Let us consider \(a,b \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(gcd(a,b) = 1\) and \(S = \langle a, b \rangle\). Let us prove that \(\{[(b,0), (0,a)]\}\) is a minimal presentation of \(S\). Given \([(\alpha_1, \beta_1), (\alpha_2, \beta_2)] \in \ker(\phi)\), and with loss of generality let us suppose \(\alpha_1 > \alpha_2\), we have
\[
\alpha_1a + \beta_1b = \phi(\alpha_1, \beta_1) = \phi(\alpha_2, \beta_2) = \alpha_2a + \beta_2 b
\]
\[
\Longleftrightarrow (\alpha_1 - \alpha_2)a = (\beta_2 - \beta_1)b.
\]
From this equality, it is deduced that exists \(q \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(\alpha_1 = \alpha_2 + bq\) and \(\beta_2 = \beta_1 + aq\). Therefore,
\[
[(\alpha_1, \beta_1), (\alpha_2, \beta_2)] = [(\alpha_2, \beta_1), (\alpha_2, \beta_1)] + q[(b,0), (0,a)].
\]
Finally, is minimal since it only has one element.
